The morning the email arrived, the mist clung to the River Exe like breath on a mirror. The cathedral bells were still sulking about last night’s vespers and the gulls were arguing over the end of a pasty someone had abandoned on the quay. That was Exeter in June: too much sky, too much history, everything the colour of postcards and old coins. I liked it like that. I liked the quiet, the illusion that I could hear my own sentences forming before they even wanted to be written down.

“You’re early,” Imogen said, chalking the specials board at the café, squinting towards me like it might wander off.

“Couldn’t sleep,” I said. “There was a fox fight under my window. Sounded like a violin saw losing an argument with a cat.”

She snorted and flicked a strand of red hair off her forehead. “Flat white?”

“Please. And those almond croissants that pretend they’re not actually cake.”

“You need to call your agent and make her buy them for you.”

“She told me last week all I need is fresh air and patience.”

“I say this with love, Rowan: Clemency is a menace.”

“She gets me paid,” I said, and sat by the big window where the river pretended to know me and the students did not. I opened my laptop; the screen blinked, indignant, and told me there were thirty-two new emails, three of them from my mother, one from my bank, and one with a subject line I didn’t understand even when I read it twice.

Britain’s Got Talent – Final Invitation.

I thought it was a prank. Of course I did. I closed the lid and opened it again like the machine might correct itself if I made it yawn. The subject line persisted, as brazen as a busker on Fore Street. Imogen set down the flat white and the almond croissant and leaned in until I could smell the coffee and her shampoo.

“Bad news?” she said, too cheerful.

“Potentially good news. Unlikely news. Very 2010-YouTube news.”

“That’s… a lot of adjectives.”

“I’m going to break the unwritten code and read an email in public.”

“You will be struck by lightning immediately.”

I clicked it open. The logo was there, red and blue and starry, and the greeting was formal in a way that made me sit up straighter. They referenced my audition months ago, the one I had nearly not gone to because my train had broken down near Taunton and I’d had to get a lift in the back of a man’s van that smelled of pine-scented cleaner and despair. They referenced the broadcast, the unexpected clip that had apparently gone viral because I told a story about my father and a blackbird in front of four judges who weren’t expecting a story about my father and a blackbird. They wrote: We would be honoured if you would take part in the live final as our Judges’ Wildcard.

My mouth worked before sound came out. “They want me,” I said, a whisper to no one, and then louder: “They want me.”

“Who?” Imogen said, craning her neck like a pole vaulter approaching the bar.

“Britain’s Got Talent.”

She misheard. “Britain’s got salad?”

“Oh for— no. The show. The actual show.”

Imogen put down the chalk. It rolled off the ledge and clattered onto the floor, a white scar on black tile. “Oh my God,” she said. “Are you joking? You hate talent shows.”

“I don’t hate them.” I tasted the lie, buttery. “I hate the idea of being judged like a particularly anxious sponge cake by people I’ve never met.”

“Did you watch that year with the dog who balanced on a bicycle?”

I thought of the dog, I thought of its eyes, the way its owner had looked like he might burst into confetti. I had watched, of course. We all had. I had also watched the year a comedian came third place and then sold out a tour in under three hours. We love to scoff; we love to be surprised. “Yes,” I said. “And the opera singer. And the girl with the violin in flames.”

Imogen took my wrist. “You’re going to write something that makes them all cry and wash their faces with their sleeve ends in their living rooms like the nation at the end of a rainy war.”

“People don’t have sleeve ends anymore. We do hoodies.”

“You’re deflecting. Call your agent. And also tell your mother. Preferably in that order.”

So I did. I took my coffee outside because I felt too restless to be contained by four walls and someone else’s music. The sky was undecided. Pigeons performed whatever family drama pigeons perform. I phoned Clemency first, because I am occasionally a professional.

She answered on the third ring. “Rowan. If this is about the invoice I forwarded, I swear on my favourite silk scarf—”

“It’s not. They want me for the final.”

“Who does?”

“Britain’s Got Talent.”

A significant pause crackled down the line, followed by the sound of a drawer slamming, a thought being pulled tight. “Well. That’s not nothing.”

“Is it madness?” I said. “Be honest.”

“I can be honest in layers. Layer one: exposure. Layer two: the booking fee, which is not dreadful. Layer three: legal. We will look at the contract and we will scrawl upon it like eighteenth-century clerks with gout. Layer four: what is your stomach doing?”

“Somersaults. Headstands. That thing you tried to teach me at the Christmas party where you jump and twist and land and pretend you didn’t nearly die.”

“Here’s my real question. Why did you audition in the first place if you were going to be this much of a stoat about it when they said yes?”

“I thought they would say no,” I said, surprising myself with the rawness of it. “I went because I… because it was a dare.”

“From whom?”

“From myself. From Devon in January. From a page that wouldn’t fill itself. I wanted to do something that didn’t feel like being buried alive under polite reviews.”

Clemency exhaled. “Then the answer is yes. We say yes. We make the best suit out of it that we can. You write a piece that fists the country and pulls it forward by the scruff into some… adequate consolation. And you don’t look at the comments.”

“I never look at the comments.”

“Ha. You look at the comments like a man peeking under a door for monsters. I’ll call you in an hour. Send me the email.”

“I will.” I paused. “Do you think I’ll embarrass myself?”

“Daily, darling. But never for the wrong reasons.”

I rang off and phoned my mother and told her before she saw it on Facebook from Linda who lives down the road and collects porcelain hedgehogs. Mum cried a little, which is her honestly, and then said she would record it for Aunt Joy and could she come up to London and sit in the audience.

“We’ll see,” I said, already imagining her knitting something inappropriate during the ad breaks. “It might be complicated. There are forms.”

“What will you read?” she said, the old worry under the new cheerfulness. “Not the one about the divorce. Your uncle Nigel didn’t understand that one.”

“I’m not sure yet.”

“Do that one about the blackbird.”

“I might do… something else,” I said, because I was superstitious and because I had promised it to myself. “Something new.”

“Don’t forget to eat before you go on live television. I’ll send you some of my flapjacks. They travel.”

“It’s not a famine, Mum.”

“They travel,” she said, which is to say, this is love, accept it.

After the calls, I walked. Past the Cathedral Green where teenagers lay in reckless formations like punctuation after exams. Past the second-hand bookshop that always smelled faintly of soup and tender embarrassment. Past the charity shop where in the window a mannequin wore a sequinned dress that had once had a story, probably involving a night with too much karaoke and the sort of dancing that leaves you grateful to be alive in the morning. Exeter is full of previously loved things. It makes a person think.

I think that year had made me smaller. The book had not done badly, if you measured the success of a book by the number of paperbacks standing to attention in the Staff Picks section with a Post-it note that said: Beautiful! Good for Dad! or by the number of times a man in a fleece at a village fair told me he had read it on his Kindle and liked the bit with the cat. But there is a way in which the internet and the London parties and the rush of it all take your face and flatten it into a caricature you stop recognising. I had moved back to Exeter to remember the smell of yeast in the morning, the way the tide finally gives in, the quiet joy of writing something that only a few people might ever read and it not killing me.

And then I had auditioned.

It was Ollie’s fault; he runs the spoken-word night above the bicycle shop on Sidwell Street, the one with the dangerously uneven stair. He had said, “Do something public for once,” and I had said, “You’re insufferable,” and then I had found myself in a queue of people with tap shoes and dogs and an illusionist who tried to guess my PIN and got it wrong twice and then got it right, which I do not think about because it makes the back of my neck prickle. I told my blackbird story to the four judges and an audience who looked like they had been trained to enjoy things. The first judge said something about truth and the second judge asked if my father was watching which made me think about grief on television. The audience stood up, some of them, like men in churches who have forgotten the hymn but stand anyway because everyone else is standing. Somebody backstage hugged me. I went home and hid for a week.

Now there was this email and my phone was a drum.

Back at the flat, the foxes had retreated to wherever they retreat during God’s sensible hours and the neighbour’s baby had given up crying so completely I held my breath until I heard a small noise and could breathe again. My desk was in the window and from it I could see the top of the cathedral and, if I stood, the river lifting and lowering whatever driftwood it had persuaded into a relationship. I opened a new document on the laptop. The empty page was a mouth.

I typed: What is the strangest thing you have ever believed about yourself, and who told you it was true?

It sat there, slightly ridiculous. It reminded me of the sort of questions teenagers scrawl on the covers of their maths books when they are meant to be doing equations. I deleted it and wrote: In Exeter, the swifts arrive in a rush as if somebody remembered to turn on a switch in the sky.

That was better. Not original in the way that makes people weep, but true. There is a way you can start something that tells a listener they may unclench their jaw because you will be kind. Or at least, you will not be needlessly cruel. I wrote for twenty minutes, and for twenty minutes I forgot the email and the judges and the country and my bank balance and the way you are always performing even as you pretend not to be.

The baby upstairs resumed the measurable, healthy crying of the well looked after. I made a sandwich. I made tea. I sent the email to Clemency. She sent back seven questions, each with two sub-clauses and the sort of bold-typed phrases that make a person grateful and itchy. I put my phone face down and forced myself to write another paragraph.

At two in the afternoon, there was a knock that sounded like a boy about to apologise for breaking a window. It was Ollie in a jacket with elbow patches and a grin that made me pity his students. He teaches English at the college and has the air of a man who will smuggle a poem into your pockets while you are busy buying chips.

“Is it true?” he said, shoulders already shaping themselves into a story he would tell later.

“Yes,” I said. “It is ridiculous and true.”

“Are you going to write about Exeter on national television? Because I swear to God, if you turn us into a rustic cliché I will—”

“Throw a cream tea at me? Yes. Unhelpful. Also please don’t. Scones stain.”

He came in without asking because that’s the sort of friend he is and sat at my table and looked at the blank document like it was a slow dog. “What are you going to do?”

“I thought— I think— something new. Something that’s shaped like a conversation you might have with the version of yourself that stopped believing it could be anything at thirteen.”

“That is simultaneously specific and vague.”

“Vague is a writer’s tool.”

“Vague is what you use when you haven’t got to the heart of it and you’re scared you won’t be able to.”

“Thank you. Do you practice this? You should be a therapist and undercharge on purpose.”

“I love you too,” he said, softening. “Listen. I’m pleased for you beyond reason. And I also want to ask if you’re ready for the fact that people will not understand what you’re doing and will shout at their televisions about you being a man who reads instead of a person who sings and then will go online and say so.”

“I’ve been a man who reads instead of a person who sings my whole life. At least now there will be a costume.”

“One of those micro-phones that fit over your ear and make you look like a secret agent borrowing your own face?”

“Exactly.” I held my own ear as if measuring for something. “Do you… want to listen?”

“To you reading? Yes. To you floundering? Also yes. I’m a complex friend.”

I read him the swifts. I read him the thought about thirteen. I read him a paragraph about my grandfather’s watch that had not yet found its purpose. He cried a little, because he is carefully constructed to appear gruff and is actually a puddle with eyebrows. When he had finished crying, he looked at me with the expression he wears when a student writes something that makes him feel like the world might not be such a tired machine after all.

“It’s not finished,” I said.

“It’s not finished,” he agreed, “and it’s still… it’s a start that could be an ending. You often start like that.”

“And you think it’s good?”

“I think it’s you. I think it’s you doing the thing your mother calls showing off and your worst reviewer calls self-absorbed and your best reader calls home.”

When he left, the late light had begun to do that thing it does in June where it makes you feel like nothing is permitted to end. I wrote. I wrote until my wrist hurt and my shoulder clicked and the rented flat smelled faintly of ink because I had pulled out the old fountain pen to stop myself from checking my email. When I finally sat back, the paragraph about the watch had become a list of the things I had thought would measure me: exam results; first kisses; word counts; the number of cities I could convincingly pretend to belong to; the speed at which I could forgive people; the ease with which I could forgive myself. It wasn’t a list that would win anything. It might be a list that could hold someone for three minutes while they waited for the adverts to end and dinner to not burn.

Clemency phoned at half six and told me the contract was mostly reasonable and the part about rights was not dreadful and that she would insist on a clause that allowed me to read a specific piece without alteration. “Also,” she said, “avoid any casual use of the word ‘bugger’.”

“I seldom use bugger casually,” I said, which is true.

“And wear a jacket. Something that reminds people of their English teacher but less harried.”

“Shouldn’t we be careful? I don’t want to look like I am in costume as someone safe.”

“You are safe. They will have pyro on stage. You are the opposite of pyro. That is your advantage.”

After I put down the phone, I went for another walk. I went up to the top of the hill where the allotments hold themselves quiet. A man was watering runner beans; he had that absorbed expression of someone who has been given a task and wants desperately to do it right. He glanced up and nodded as if to say: yes, we are all trying. A girl with a purple streak in her hair sat on the grass and blasted music that used to be called grime and is now called something else, because time forgets us so gently. I stood and watched the city be itself. You can go to London for the feeling that the whole world is happening at once like a party where you might miss the most important thing if you even blink. Exeter gives you the feeling that there is a book open on a table somewhere and you have time to read it and maybe pass it along.

Back at the flat, I showered and put on a T-shirt that had survived longer than some friendships. I ate pasta and watched a quiz show where no one won more than a hundred pounds and still seemed delighted to have been on the television. I went to bed with my phone across the room like a child in time-out. I dreamt about being in a library where all the books were unlabelled and I had to guess which was mine by the weight.

In the morning, the mist burned clean off the river. I woke with a sentence stuck to my tongue like a seed. I reached for the notebook by the bed and wrote: You are not what you win.

It looked too obvious and also like the answer to a riddle I hadn’t asked properly yet. The kettle complained itself into a bit of purpose. The email arrived from the show’s producer with times and dress rehearsals and a reminder that there would be a meeting with the judges’ team and would I be so good as to bring two options for my piece so their standards and practices department could have a moment to panic at leisure.

I phoned my mother again and told her to please, please not tell anyone until the announcement was official. She agreed and then accidentally told Linda who told Aunt Joy who sent me a message that contained only a string of confetti emojis and a picture of her cat wearing a fascinator. I forwarded it to Imogen who wrote back: If the cat is available to stand in for you, that could be plan B.

At lunchtime, I took the train to Paignton and back for no reason other than the movement helps. The man opposite me ate a sausage roll slowly and then fell asleep with his mouth slightly open and I wanted to write him down, to put him in a story where he gets precisely what he wants and it is not a sausage roll. The carriage rocked. The windows did their best to show me the sea.

When I got home, there was an envelope under my door with Ollie’s handwriting. Inside it, there were three photos from the open-mic night last winter. In one of them, I am reading with my head tilted as if listening for something. In one, I am laughing at something someone else is saying and my shoulder is relaxed, which is so rare in photographs of me I put it on the fridge for my own reassurance. He’d written on the back of the third: You are allowed to take up space without apologising. Also bring spare pens.

The second day after the email, I got a text that made the back of my neck heat up as if a small sun had rolled right behind me and waited. It wasn’t from the show. It was from a number that I hadn’t saved and yet recognised in a muscle deep enough I had to sit down.

Heard a rumour. E x.

E x was not a typo. It was Eliot Pike’s way of performing his wit even with an initial. Eliot with one L and the o smoothed out like a pebble, a man who had once told me that ‘Rowan Vale’ sounded too much like a woodland and not enough like a person. He had been in my first workshop in London, the kind where everyone tries to hide their ambition under a cardigan. He had a laugh that made you feel like you’d told the joke wrong. He had a way of owning the room that meant the room spent the rest of the day trying to get itself back. We had both applied for the same grant; he had got it and sent me a message that said: Hope there’s a next time, which was to congratulations what margarine is to butter. We had both been shortlisted for the same prize; I had won; he had sent me a page-long letter about the things prizes cannot possibly measure which, at the time, I had thought magnanimous until someone pointed out the sting at the end where he had told me, gently, that my work was “good company for train journeys.”

The rumour, I guessed, was my rumour.

I put the phone on the table like you might put down something heavy you didn’t mean to lift. And then I did the thing I had told Clemency I would not do. I typed his name into the search bar of the internet and watched it produce a small circus. There he was in a velvet jacket on a radio show. There he was in black and white, the darling of a magazine that still pretended it didn’t read its own press releases. There was a post from a production assistant of a televised talent show, blurred faces in a corridor, captioned: This line-up is going to be ridiculous, accompanied by metadata that made my stomach feel like I had swallowed a hedgehog.

It would not be him, I told myself. He would not lower himself to stand on the same stage that dog had balanced a bicycle. Eliot would host an untelevised salon where the art would be too delicate to be broadcast. He would—

My phone buzzed again. From Clemency this time, blessedly human. Call me when you can, she wrote. And nothing else. Not an emoji, not even a dot.

I phoned. She answered at once. “Don’t say anything until I have said something,” she said, which is a sentence that never means good news. “And don’t throw your phone.”

“I…” I looked at the phone in my hand the way a person looks at a dog that is about to bolt. “Clemency?”

“The show wants you. That hasn’t changed. The show also wants to be television. Which means it has to be full of stories people can read while they are boiling pasta. One such story is: Rivalry. Historical bad blood. The return. You see where I’m going.”

“You’re about to say a name, aren’t you.”

She did. “Eliot Pike is also on the final. He is doing an ‘experimental narrative performance’. His words, not mine. He told the producers that he invented the genre of whatever you do.”

“That seems likely. He also invented the height of tables, the feeling of tasting fennel for the first time, and the concept of polite cruelty.”

“Rowan.”

“I’m fine,” I lied. “I’m not fine. How do we—”

“We do nothing.” She was the calm in my boat. “You write your piece. You dress like an adult. You do the thing you have to do to make yourself sleep at night. If you allow him into your head you will put him on stage with you. He does not deserve to be on stage with you unless he paid for the ticket.”

“It will be easier for the show if he’s the villain.”

“It will be easier for everyone if we don’t play along with anyone’s plan to make you anything other than the man who talks about swifts.”

“I wrote something this morning,” I said, and I told her the line from the notebook. There was a silence at the end of it like the silence you get at the top of a hill.

“Good,” she said. “Good. Put it on a Post-it. Stick it somewhere. Read it every time his name tries to colonise your mood.”

After we hung up, I sat at the desk and watched the river pull itself along. My chest had that buzz in it like a hive you are not exactly sure belongs to you. I could see the story unrolling in the papers: once-friends-at-odds, Devon vs. Dalston, two men with words in their mouths like teeth. I could see people picking sides, as if there were sides to pick, as if we were a football match and not two people pretending to be less fragile than we are. I could feel the tug—perform the argument, take back the room that time he took, settle it finally in the place where you hope television might bear witness.

I made tea. I ate an apple. I did not look at my phone. I opened the document and I read the swifts and the watch and the list and the line I had written in the morning. I cut a paragraph that was clever and cruel and would have gotten me a laugh and an email from my mother. I put in a sentence about my father’s garden fork leaning against a shed through a decade of weather. I put in one about the exact sound of an audience holding its breath.

I read it aloud. The room held me. My kitchen table, my plant that I had finally kept alive for more than a year, the chair with the scrape on the back from when I had moved in: they were the small and domestic audience that will tell you if you are lying. I do not think I was lying yet.

The next days were a blur of practice and emails and avoiding the part of the internet that wanted to tell me what to do with myself. Imogen brought me a cake with the Union Jack iced on top in a way that made it look like it had been run over by a bike. “Patriotic,” she said. “Symbolic. Tastier than the actual Union.”

“I will not be eating sugar before a live television broadcast,” I said, and then I ate two slices and gave the rest to the seagulls.

Ollie stood in my kitchen and clapped me between paragraphs. He threw a tea towel at my head when I got too solemn. He pretended to be each of the judges and said things like, “Tell me why you’re doing this now,” in a voice that verged on sinister and then laughed at his own acting. Clemency sent me pictures of jackets. My mother posted a picture of a cake tin to our family WhatsApp group and wrote: Practising. There was a breeze through the city that made the bunting flicker even where there was no bunting.

On the Friday before the Sunday of the final, I took the train to London. The carriage was crowded with bright children and tired parents and one man with a saxophone that did not, at any point, erupt into music. The fields unrolled like someone’s idea of consolation. On my lap was a folder with two versions of a thing that could, if I stood right and breathed, carry me through three minutes and thirty seconds.

As the train pulled into Paddington, my phone buzzed again. A message from a number I had not saved because I know myself: Eliot. Good luck, it said, and below that, unkindly, the picture of a thumbs-up.

I typed nothing in response. I put the phone in my pocket. I got off the train into a city that smelled of metal and late plans and held my bag tighter so I would not forget who it belonged to.

In the hotel room paid for by television, I watched myself in the mirror. You do not have to like him, I told the reflection. You don’t even have to feel anything at all about him. You are allowed to feel everything else. I put on the jacket that made me look like a teacher and a cousin. I put the second version of the piece back in the folder and then took it out again and then put it back, which in the world of the undecided stands in for faith.

I walked to a park near the studio and read under a plane tree while teenagers performed the ritual of pretending to be indifferent to each other and adults performed the ritual of thinking about not going back to work and then doing it anyway. On a bench, a man fed a small child banana slices and ate the ones that fell in his own lap like a person who has learned the economies of love. I breathed. I said hello to a dog in my head so that I would be the kind of person who says hello to a dog.

When the call came to go into the studio for the technical rehearsal, I had already walked through the piece enough that my mouth knew where it was going. The stage swallowed me in that way stages do, the lights like warm fists, the seating rising, empty, like the promise of a storm. A person with a headset said my name to someone I could not see in a voice that meant we were now a show and not this day in my life. I stood on the taped cross on the floor and looked at the camera with its apathetic eye and tried not to imagine anyone hiding behind it, ready to judge and ready, too, to be kind if I gave them the instruction.

“Sound check,” a man said, and I said, “Exeter” and “swifts” and “blackbird,” and the words hung there, audible even in this air that smelled of electricity and old plastic.

On a riser to my left, someone said, “Rowan. You look exactly the same,” and I didn’t have to turn to know who it was, though of course I did turn, because I am polite.

Eliot stood there in a black shirt that did not belong to any shop I could afford and trousers that looked like he had borrowed them from a dancer. He smiled in that way of his that meant: see me noticing you.

“Thank you,” I said, the two words as lined up as I could make them.

He came down the steps, two at a time. “I’m glad they did the sensible thing,” he said. “It makes for a better narrative.”

“I think they call it a ‘package’,” I said, because I have a petty part that wanted him to hear me say their word with my mouth. “We’ll try not to ruin their edit.”

He laughed. “What are you reading?”

“What are you doing?” I asked at the same time, and then we both were quiet for a second and I thought of being nineteen and in a kitchen at a party where everyone is performing their cleverness and the single mercy is someone handing you a glass of water unironically.

“Something honest,” he said, which was his joke, and his not-joke. “Try not to be sentimental,” he added, lightly, like a man recommending a dessert.

“I’m not sure what you think that word means.”

“I know exactly what it means,” he said. “It’s what you do. You domesticate feeling and take it for a walk on a lead.”

He stood there, handsome and infuriating, and I felt the old doors in me shift. There it was, the invitation to fight inside his sentences. I shook my head like a man shaking rain from his ears. “Have a good rehearsal,” I said, and I meant it more than I wanted to.

He watched me walk to my tape mark. He clapped once, the sound swallowed by the empty room. The person with the headset said, “From the top, please,” and I breathed, because somewhere between Exeter and here I had decided to be the person who does not pretend they are not always breathing for the first time.

You are not what you win, I thought. You are not what you win. You are the man who will go home and write again. The technical cue light blinked. The time ticked down. I opened my mouth. And said what I had to say.The first run-through felt like taking a pulse in a hurricane. I knew where my breath went and where the jokes were, the small pockets of air where people might laugh and forgive me for letting them. I knew the cadence I wanted for the sentence about the watch, the place where I wanted to pause so the old man watering his runner beans could walk across the stage of other people’s imaginations and take his time. On the empty seats a crew member had taped sheets of paper with names written in thick black marker, and reading to those names was like reading to ghosts who had bought their tickets early. A woman with a headset and the patient expression of a midwife leaned close to remind me that the red light meant yes and the floor edge meant no and that if the pyro went off for the dance troupe before me I would see the scorch marks and not to be alarmed because everything was under control. I thanked her as if she had personally invented control.

Afterwards, Nisha from Standards and Practices took me aside to say, only slightly apologetically, that “damn” was probably acceptable but we should lose “bloody” in the context of my grandfather’s watch because they were keen on keeping the pre-watershed audience on our side. I told her that would be fine, and we stood for a moment looking at the taped X on the stage that was mine as if it were an ambiguous omen. She was kind in that unshowy way people are kind when their whole job is to prevent catastrophe without ever appearing on camera. When I told her I’d once said “bugger” on local radio by accident and that the presenter had pretended he hadn’t heard, she laughed, and it felt like the studio exhaled with us.

The green room was less green than I wanted, more beige and snack-coloured, bowls of crisps and grapes and chocolate bars making a low offer to every nervous system in the place. On one sofa, a magician practised shuffling with a deck so worn it looked like a family heirloom; next to him, a woman in a sequinned leotard folded herself into a shape that made everyone else sit up straighter out of respect. A child with a ventriloquist’s dummy on his knee watched cartoons on a tablet with the sort of concentration that could have powered a small town, while his mother asked him, every four minutes, if he needed the toilet. A choir arrived late and breathed as one organism while their choirmaster held up his hands like a man holding back heavy machinery. Everyone had a ritual. Mine was to drink water and then drink more water and then put the bottle down and forget which bottle was mine and start again.

Eliot appeared, of course, in a sigh of other people’s attention. He wore black in a way that suggested it cost more than my rent and had been steamed by someone with a postgraduate degree. He didn’t look at me as he talked to his director, or he did but only in split-second glances that were a kind of currency. It was a relief, terrible and pure, the way you feel when you realise that a person you have been braced to hate is just another person navigating the snacks and the lighting gel and the producers who say things like, “Can you give me that again but with even more sense of… stakes?” I watched him rehearse a line in the corridor that I recognised from an event the year before where he’d stood in front of an audience on a barge and told them about a man who mistook longing for taste. It was better now. He is, I have to admit, good at what he does. It made me love what I do harder.

I escaped into a stairwell that smelled like dust and floor polish and texted Imogen a photograph of my shoes because they looked like a teacher’s shoes in an advert for adulthood. She replied, immediately: You could hide a small dictionary in those. Also do you want me to send you a picture of the scones I made to keep my hands busy while you do something terrifying? I told her I did, and she sent me an image of three ambitious scones, one leaning slightly, all dusted with sugar like a blessing. The kindness of people who cannot get to a television studio but can get to an oven is not to be underestimated.

Before the dress rehearsal, there was a meeting with one of the judges’ producers, a woman whose cardigan gave away nothing. She sat me down in a corner that had somehow been furnished like a quiet room and asked what I wanted people to know about me in three sentences or fewer. I told her I was from Devon and that I liked rivers and that I was sorry. She smiled and said, “We can work with Devon and rivers.” Then she asked if I had a message. It is hard to be asked that question without wanting to become a sandwich board. I said something about not measuring joy in units they can sell you, and she made a note with a very nice pen and reminded me that if any of the judges asked about Eliot I could say I was excited to perform on the same night as someone I respect. I practised saying it and found it did not kill me.

The dress rehearsal taught me the precise length of three minutes and thirty seconds. It is not very long, and it is forever. They miked me up, the pale loop over my ear like the ghost of a fishhook, and checked the tape for my name a third time. The lighting operator walked me through the journey my face would take from shadow to clarity; he called it a build, and I watched the floor dots glow and then turn shy. It was impossible not to think of school plays and church halls and those charity gala nights in which I had leaned into a microphone that smelled of beer and begged it to behave. The director, a man with hair that looked exactly as expensive as his patience, asked if I would be happy to take one step left at the end of the second paragraph so the camera could find me. I said I would be happy to take one step left at any time if someone would simply tell me when to do it. He laughed, and someone in a booth said, “Copy that,” and for a second it felt like the most beautiful machine in the world.

The hotel they’d put me in had a soft-focus view of a railway line and a coffee machine that made a sound like a distant cow. The bed was too large and too clean for me to sleep without suspicion, so I lay on top of the duvet reading the poem Eliot had published last month about a woman eating an orange in a train station. It was technically immaculate and emotionally unkind to everyone involved, including the orange. I put it down and picked up my own pages and changed a comma because the page wanted it and because changing things is a way the anxious make a shrine of control. When I turned off the light, the city hum sat outside the window like a cat I hadn’t let in.

In the morning my mother phoned from a train that was both at Clapham Junction and nowhere at all. She told me Aunt Joy had bought a fascinator whose ambition outstripped its engineering and asked whether she was allowed to knit during the adverts. I told her that I loved her and that she had to promise, promise, not to accost any of the other contestants in the corridor and give them toffees from her bag. She said she could not promise it but would try. In the background I could hear the sound of Linda’s travel mug clattering against something and a small explosion of laughter. I told them which queue to join and which line to say when the security guard asked who they were there for and wrote it out on a piece of paper as if they would have time to read my handwriting at the door.

Back at the studio, David the stage manager handed me a mug of hot water with lemon and honey and informed me without preamble that he had done seventeen series and that in his experience the difference between the people who enjoyed themselves and the people who did not was not talent but the decision to enjoy themselves. He had eyes like the sky over Exeter when it had finally made up its mind to be kind and a pencil behind his ear that looked like an extra finger. He told me a story about a man who had frozen mid-song and then recovered by telling the audience he had imagined them in their underpants and found them disappointingly fashionable, and how the audience had loved him for the confession. “If you forget,” he said, “tell them. They love to be told the truth from people who look like you.”

An hour before the live show, they took us to the stage for a last walk-through. From the wings I could see the seats filling, the audience learning their lines from the warm-up comic who stood on the stage like a minister at the altar of laughter and taught them to cheer when a hand went up and boo when a cue line suggested scandal. They practised clapping, which you would think the nation had already got the hang of, but it turns out we like to be told when and how to be enthusiastic if we suspect our enthusiasm might otherwise be inefficient. The judges took their seats to the sort of entrance music that says: you will tell stories about having been in the presence of this personality. The camera swooped; the floor thrummed. Someone brushed powder along my forehead and asked me questions I couldn’t hear because my heart had turned itself up to be heard over my head.

I saw my mother. It was not likely, and it was also inevitable. She was in row H, wearing a cardigan that had been nice before she wore it to death and hair she had done herself with more optimism than technique. Aunt Joy’s fascinator looked like the spaceship in a science-fiction film where the heroine keeps a diary. Next to them, a woman who might have been Linda or a saint waved at me with a handkerchief she had probably brought in case anyone cried. When my mother saw me seeing her she did that thing she has done since I was five years old, where she made a face that included the whole story of my existence in one expression and then made a small fist and pumped it as if we were at a football match and the team had finally learned to pass.

I stood on the X when they told me to stand on the X. The noise of the room changed. It is a strange sound, the sound a crowd makes when it decides to listen as one person. The red light on the camera became a small, benign planet. The music dropped away and I could hear only the soles of my shoes on the floor and a man in the back row coughing the kind of cough that insists on its own innocence. The host said my name in the shape the nation had decided to give it. The applause came and went like a tide. Somewhere, thousands of people adjusted themselves on sofas, picked a bit of dinner from a plate, looked at me without looking at me. I breathed.

I said: In Exeter, the swifts arrive in a rush as if somebody remembered to flick the switch and turn on the sky, and you can feel the city notice. People don’t look up enough, but they do that day. You can hear it, the noticing, the way we hear the bin lorry, the way we hear the person we love coming up the stairs and, even before they put the key in the door, we prepare our faces to be kind.

I told them the thing I had to tell them about being thirteen and believing the worst thing I could be was not clever but ordinary, and no one thought to correct me because it sounded like a kind of ambition. I said that if you asked me to list the things that had measured me I could give you a catalogue that would make your fingers ache: test scores, library cards, the number of times I could hold a person’s eye without looking away, the ages at which I gave things up and the ages at which I learned to pick them back up without apologising. People smiled in the front row in that way people do when their faces remember a room they used to be in.

I told them about my grandfather’s watch leaning in a drawer for a decade because I was afraid to wind it. I told them about my father’s garden fork standing against the shed through weather so attentive it grew us into whatever we had managed to be. I told them about a blackbird because if you’re given a stage this large you might as well bring someone you love with you. He used to sing into our kitchen like he was on a mission to improve the boiling of potatoes and we, stupidly, thought he would be available forever. I said the word father once and felt the room hold itself like a pan lifted off the boil and then set gently back down.

I said, You are not what you win. You are not what you fail to win. You are not even, on the worst days, what the worst person thinks of you when they are having their worst day. You are the person who, quietly, without permission, grows a life like ivy along a fence you didn’t know you wanted until it was there. You are the person who writes a list of small mercies and then reads it twice, out loud, in a kitchen, to a plant that has decided to live. This is not a trick and it is not an apology. It is the opposite of a trick. It is the cupboard we keep the good mugs in. It is ordinary, which is to say, it will save us.

I finished at the place where the piece finished, a place it had chosen for itself, and the build on the lights did what it had promised. For a second that was so dense it felt like a physical object, there was nothing, no sound but the metal of the rig cooling and the microscopic shift of a hundred postures. Then the audience did the thing audiences do with relief and clapping and the occasional involuntary noise that comes out of a person when they have to. The host walked in from the wings with that balance of sincerity and performance he keeps in his pocket. I remembered to step left, and the camera found me like a bird landing exactly where it means to. Someone in row H stood up too quickly and then sat down again with their whole body in a blush.

The judges made their noises. The comedian judge said he had not planned to cry on a Sunday but that at least the nation would not mistake him for a statue, and he made a joke about his mascara that made everyone love him more. The music judge said my piece was a song without music and that her mother would phone her immediately to tell her I reminded her of someone whose name I did not catch. The impresario judge, whose teeth could have lit a minor motorway, said that I had a gift for making the small things large and the large things small, which is not what art is supposed to do and also exactly what it does when it is behaving. The fourth judge, who has won awards for being sensible in public, told me that she had written down a line and that she would not say which one because private things are allowed on television if you decide they are. I thanked them in the order I had been told to thank them and did not try to be clever because cleverness is shy in this kind of light and runs away if you make eye contact.

Backstage, the man with the lemon and honey put the mug back into my hand and said, “That went,” and I could not disagree. I had a spasm of shaking that was not fit for the camera and hid behind a curtain that had seen too much to judge me. Someone from digital content asked if they could film a clip of me giving advice to my younger self and I said later, which is a thing I have learned to say only recently. My phone did what it always does when I am briefly visible to more people than usual; it filliped with messages like a fish in a net. I did not look. Clemency arrived in a gust of perfume and relief and told me not to look at anything not wearing a nametag.

Eliot touched my elbow. He had watched from the wings and he was good enough to wait until my face had come back. He said, “I liked the line about the cupboard,” and it was the kindest thing he had said to me in five years and I wanted both to bite him and to tell him it was about my mother and the mugs she will not allow anybody else to wash. He was already moving away, his body adjusting itself for the camera’s appetite. In the distance, his own set waited, all angles and blackness and a chair with more meaning than chairs generally have. I went to sit in the green room and shared crisps with the child ventriloquist while his dummy practised blinking. The acrobat cracked her back like a brief thunderclap and told me that nerves were proof of respect. The choir sang a quiet G under their breath like a hymn for people in corridors.

Watching Eliot from the monitor is a dangerous sport if your heart has already done enough work for the week. He did what he does, which is make language into a knife that somehow, when it cuts you, reveals something you had wanted to see. He leaned on a sentence as if it were furniture. He talked about hunger and fashion and a photograph of himself at nineteen that he had kept in a drawer for when he needed to remember what not to do. He was merciless, including to the version of himself he brought out like evidence. The audience laughed when he asked them to and sighed when he permitted it, and I hated every second that I admired him. When he finished, the room made a noise as if it had discovered a brand-new way to agree about something.

If there was a narrative, it had improved itself in the edit. The host threw to an advert break with the speed of a man catching a falling plate. I could feel the nation stand up and collect bowls and have opinions. The part of me that is a medieval peasant looked for portents in the signs, counted the cheers, measured the humidity, watched the tiny rain that was confetti from the dance troupe floating down through lights to stick to the taped X on the stage like snow that had gone to finishing school. The part of me that is a person tried to remember the train back to Exeter and whether I had left the heating set to reasonable.

Between the live performances and the voting come the interviews that look spontaneous and smell of planning. In ours the host asked if we were friends and we did the thing where we laughed and said we respected each other’s work and kept our bodies still and behaved like adults. Eliot made a quip about how television loves to pretend people live in binary and the audience clapped at the word pretend because it sounded like a commentary without requiring them to do anything about it. The camera moved on. The band played a song from a decade I do not feel old enough to call a decade. The crew rearranged the stage to make room for a man who would juggle knives and grief.

By the time the voting closed, I was so clean of expectation I could almost feel the aftertaste of it, the way you taste garlic the next day because it has colonised you in a pleasant way. I sat shoulder to shoulder with a boy who had stilt-walked in a suit that made him look like a friendly Greek god and held his hand because his mother asked me to. I ran into my own mother in a corridor because the universe will give you what you love when it can and because security are wonderful but cannot entirely contain Aunt Joy when she is wearing a hat that could guide sea traffic. They had found the free water and a marshal who used to live in Ottery St Mary had said something that had made my mother decide he would come to Christmas. She pressed a gift into my pocket, something wrapped in kitchen towel and warm like it had been next to her skin. Later, in the half-light of backstage, I unwrapped it and found one of her flapjacks, the top shiny with syrup, and I bit into it in front of a woman from makeup who said, “Oh, love,” like a blessing.

We went back to the stage for the announcement. The lights did their thousand-eye thing and the floor gleamed and the host said words that became only rhythm because we had all forgotten our native tongue and had replaced it with this one. The finalists stood in a line like a new sort of choir. I could see the drummer for the house band chewing gum as if he were trying to bring the heart rate of the whole building down by a fraction. The host read out names and people stepped forward and the audience did what it had been taught. Eliot’s profile, viewed sideways, looked like a statue of a man making a sensible point. I had the sudden distinct impression that, whatever happened, I would sleep and not wake up inside a verdict. Maybe it was only the flapjack talking. Maybe it was the sentence I had taped to the inside of my skull. Maybe it was that Exeter had come with me after all, swifts humming over the river, the Cathedral bells sulking, Imogen chalking a specials board as if she could boss the day into being good.

When the red light blinked its important blink and the host took a breath that promised everyone a memory, I looked into the camera and thought of the cupboard with the good mugs in it and the person I had been who did not know you could choose to be kind to him. The hand came down on the envelope like a gavel on a mercy. The room drew its breath in with the theatre of a storm. I stood where I had been told to stand and, quietly, made myself ready to go home and write again.They said a name that was not mine and I felt, with a clarity almost medical, something inside me sit down. The lights did their theatre and the room made the sound that rooms make when they choose a story to keep, and all of it was both enormous and very far away, like thunder on the other side of a valley. I clapped for the boy with the voice that had made the balcony vibrate; I clapped for the choir who had made something communal out of breath; I clapped, with a kind of relieved ferocity, because my hands knew what to do while the rest of me recalibrated. There was a camera in my face for the “reaction,” and I arranged mine like crockery on a draining board: sincere, not tragic, usable. Somewhere to my left, Eliot put on the expression that has seen him through prize nights and bad wine, and the host said things about journeys and how far we had all come, and I remembered suddenly, stupidly, the train from Taunton and the smell of pine cleaner and despair in the back of a van.

They herded us off with admirable efficiency, as if handling a flock that had to be got to a gate before the weather turned. In the corridor, the music sounded like it was being played down a metal tube; in the green room, it sounded like nothing at all because everybody was too busy swallowing. The child with the ventriloquist’s dummy asked me if I was famous now, and I said I was famous for at least the duration of a bus ride, which made his mother laugh into her sleeve like a person who had been waiting for permission to. Clemency appeared with her arms already out and her phone already full, and she kissed my cheek and told me she was maternal with pride and allergic to disappointment and that my mentions would be a small bonfire we would not stand too close to. She gave me the wrap-up: trending, the judges had been kind, there was a producer from a radio programme who wanted me the next week, and a stranger had emailed her to say I had made him stop drinking straight out of the saucepan and get a glass.

My mother found me despite every barrier designed to keep mothers from finding their sons in television buildings. She had acquired a lanyard by smiling at a person who did not know how to deal with a woman who thanked him for his service as though he were returning from a mission. Aunt Joy’s fascinator had slid imperceptibly to port and the effect was of a ship that had seen something extraordinary on the horizon and leaned towards it. They were incandescent with the kind of joy that only partly requires facts. My mother put both her hands on my face and said, “You were beautiful,” which is a thing it is very hard to hear at any age and not become briefly three years old. Aunt Joy declared, with the certainty of someone whose entire experience of showbusiness had just occurred, that the nation had fallen in love with me and could do what it liked about it.

Eliot and I crossed paths by the precious water cooler, that diplomatic zone where every emotion has to take off its shoes. He looked exactly like a man who had been very nearly turned into a story and had only partly enjoyed the sensation. For once his precision wobbled and I could see the person under the press cuttings, a man with a habit of wrinkling his nose when he was thinking hard. He said, “You were very good,” in a tone that was almost ordinary, and I said, “You were too,” and for the first time since the barge, neither of us tried to make the compliment into a competition. It felt like someone had unthreaded a wire that had been tightened between us for so long we had forgotten it was there. Then a runner asked him to stand under a light and say something about the experience of the experience, and he was gone, unblinking in the new sun of attention.

By the time I had been collected, debriefed, congratulated and handed a tote bag with a bottle of something non-alcoholic and a T-shirt that was never going to suit me, the backstage had begun to empty of its adrenaline. A technician in a hoodie coiled cables as if they were snakes he had tamed with kindness. The floor was confettied with the evidence of other people’s moments: a broken sequin, a sentence dropped like a feather, the skid mark of a heel that had tried to stop history. David the stage manager passed me and tipped his pencil as if it were a hat and said, “Told you—decision,” and I wanted to hug him and also go somewhere my name was elastic again. Clemency kissed me once more and murmured that she would ring at eleven and noon and three tomorrow and to sleep with my phone far enough away that I could not hear it sulking. My mother tried to give me a Tupperware of egg sandwiches she had smuggled into the capital like contraband; security looked at me, I looked at security, and we all conspired to believe we lived in a world where such things were legal.

In the hotel room, the railway line moved past as if it were the last thing still committed to speed. I put the tote bag on a chair as if it were a guest and took the jacket off with the careful movements of a person taking off a personality. The quiet after that much light is not quiet at all; it’s a tide going out and pulling the bones of the day with it. I washed the make-up off my face and was briefly surprised to find my face underneath, and then I ate my mother’s egg sandwich out of the Tupperware with the grave gratitude of a pilgrim. The phone jittered on the desk like a bird getting ready to take off. I turned it face down and stood at the window and imagined the Exeter night, the river not pretending anything, Imogen closing the café with a flourish that had much more to do with her than with the till.

I slept like a person who had promised himself that sleep was not a verdict. When I woke, the city had remembered it was Monday and got on with it. Trains arrived and departed with the righteous noise of things that have purpose. I packed in that desultory way you pack when your suitcase and your heart disagree about where home is. On the train, my mother and Aunt Joy took possession of a table as if seating plans were a suggestion rather than a law. Aunt Joy shared anecdotal feedback from the women in Row H—Apparently I have an honest neck and a kind stance—and my mother read to me in fragments from messages relatives had sent from various edges of the country. Linda cried on and off like a defective tap and kept passing me items from her bag that did not immediately strike me as snacks but turned out to be snacks. We watched out of the window as the capital became fields with intention, and then hills with opinions, and then the soft domesticity of Devon sidled in like a cat forgiving you.

Back in Exeter, the air had that washed feeling it sometimes gets after a weekend when the whole city has been lent to visitors and then returned. Imogen was outside the café chalking a list of scones that read like a shortlist for a small, well-judged prize. When she saw me, she did not shout in the way I know she had been waiting to, because we are not that kind of town, but she did clap with her hands below the board, which only the seagulls and I could see. She made me sit down before I could pretend I had to go home to unpack, and she made me drink a coffee like an antidote and eat something that did not announce itself as cake until it was halfway down. “Look at you,” she said, and there was the love in it that makes a person able to be looked at. “You didn’t combust. You didn’t say bugger. You remembered to put your mouth where your heart is.”

Ollie arrived with a bag of pears that he clearly hadn’t meant to buy and the air of a man who is ready to be disappointed if it will make a better story. He peered at me as if looking for scorch marks. “How famous are you?” he asked, without preamble. “On a scale from person who gets recognised at the dump to person who cannot buy toilet roll without a minor incident.”

“I am recognised by toddlers who fear I am about to be a bedtime story,” I said. “And by men in fleeces who want to tell me about their blackbirds.”

“Perfect,” he said. “Containable fame. The best kind. We run a night on Thursday and call it ‘The Man Off The Telly Reads And Then Everybody Goes Home Before Ten.’”

He was joking, but the idea lodged in the sort of corner that collects useful fluff. The thought of reading above the bicycle shop where the stair threatens to remove your dignity every time you climb it felt like a cure for an infection I hadn’t admitted I’d caught. The studio had been a machine and a miracle; the bicycle shop would be splinters and condensation and the way people make space with their attention rather than with lights. I told him I would, if he promised to temper the poster, and he promised to do something that included only my initials and a very confused pigeon.

On Tuesday morning the emails arrived like weather. Clemency orchestrated them with the relish of a conductor discovering that the orchestra is larger than she thought. There were invites and offers and a press request that made me snort tea through my nose. A radio programme wanted me to talk about the craft of timing and whether sadness has a rhythm. A festival wanted a curated evening entitled Ordinary Things That Saved Us, which made me itch because salvation is a word that belongs to people who use it with care. A small publisher I love sent a message that read, simply, If there’s a pamphlet in it, we will find the staples and the patience. There was a letter forwarded from the show addressed to “The Gentleman Poet,” in the spindly blue biro of prison paper, which I left unopened on the table while I caught up with my breath, and then opened with that breath in my throat. It was from a man in Parc who wrote about how the sound of the swifts had made the undersides of his ribs feel like windows, and who asked if I might write him a list of small tasks to do with his hands that would not get him into trouble. I wrote back that afternoon and told him about peeling oranges with attention and counting the screws in a hinge and learning the names of the weeds nobody loves.

In the middle of the admin, a text arrived without the weighty trailer of any app. It was from a number I now no longer had to memorise to know what my stomach would do when I saw it. Nice line about the cupboard. E. There was no flourish, no baroque vocabulary. The message looked almost embarrassed to be itself. I stared at it long enough for the screen to dim and then brightened the screen with my thumb as if encouraging a shy animal. I wrote back: That orange poem was good work. R. It was not what I had to say, and it might be what it had to be for now.

After lunch, after telling my mother twice that no, I was not being asked to be a judge on anything and no, I could not arrange for Linda’s cat to be on the Christmas special, I took the old fountain pen out of its drawer. The watch sat there too, its face bleached a little by years of not being asked to help. I picked it up the way you pick up a friendship you have neglected, careful not to pretend you haven’t. My thumb found the knurled crown and I wound it until I felt the resistance change from welcome to warning. The tick it made in my palm was the least theatrical sound I had heard all day and I wanted to cry for the way we pretend small ticks are not how we stay alive. I set it down on the desk where my laptop had been sulking and let them glare at each other like rivals in a nursery.

In the evening I walked down to the river. The swifts were showing off, because of course they were, because every lesson in the world comes with an encore if you look up. The cathedral had decided not to sulk and was busy being a place where people make promises in party clothes. Tourists leaned on the parapet and let the wind edit their hair. A boy with a skateboard practised a thing I do not know the name of and failed and failed and then landed it and allowed himself one soundless celebration, like a prayer. I stood there and did the very unfashionable act of being grateful without an audience. If a television studio is a forge, the river is a sink, and sometimes you have to stand over it and wash your hands properly.

Thursday came and with it the open mic and a queue that made the bicycle shop look like it had become briefly famous in a French film. People had seen the poster with my initials and the pigeon and had made the correct assumptions. Ollie had put a string of fairy lights around the mic stand which made it look like an apology. The room smelled of chain oil and malty bread and the sort of nerves that improve a thing. I went up the stairs like a man proving he still could. Imogen stood behind the bar with the seriousness of a priest serving sacrament and told people it would be over by ten because some of us have to get up and bake at five. When I stood up and the chairs creaked and the room made that little collective surrender that rooms make when they have decided to trust you, I felt, briefly and completely, at home.

I didn’t read the television piece. I read the second version I’d put back in the folder, the one I hadn’t needed on the night and had loved quietly anyway. It was about the taste of the air on the first day of school and the way new exercise books pretend they will save you. It was about the vocabulary of small repairs and the feeling of being forgiven in a hardware shop. It was about the smell of my father’s jumper, which I still keep in a bag that once had apples in it, and about a woman on the train who broke a KitKat into four exactly equal fingers and passed the fourth to a stranger because it seemed like the law. People laughed in the places where I had left them room to and quieted so completely at the end that I could hear somebody’s coat recollecting the rain. There was no judge, no red light, no build, no camera. There was a man in a bicycle helmet who took it off like a hat. There was a girl at the back who had been chewing her sleeve and who, when I was done, put her sleeve back into her mouth like a person who has remembered herself.

After, a woman came up and told me she’d brought her father because he didn’t like poems but he did like handrails and she thought I might be a bridge. A boy with hair like nettles handed me a zine he’d stapled on a bus and said that the line about forgiving yourself had made his throat feel like it had swallowed a lightbulb and he wasn’t sure if that was good or not. Ollie pressed a bottle of beer into my hand and told me briskly not to get used to applause indoors because we don’t have room for it and people need to get back to their bikes. I walked home the long way, along the perimeter of the park where people throw balls to dogs that have learned generosity as a sport, and when I got in I wound the watch again and it ticked at me as if to say: yes, again, yes.

The next week became a rhythm that, for once, did not make me feel like I was being dragged. Mornings at the desk with the river doing its unshowy work. A radio interview done under a duvet because the room was echoey and I wanted the nation to hear only my vowels and not my ceiling. Emails from people who had seen me on the television and now wanted to see me in rooms with walls, which is a better way to see another person. A letter from the prison that had the neat lines of a man learning patience in pen. Coffee with a woman from the small publisher who wore a brooch shaped like a question mark and said, over a plate of biscuits whose ambition outstripped their butter, that perhaps I had a pamphlet, and perhaps it should be called Kindness Will Not Save Us But We Could Try Being Kind Anyway, and I grinned so wide the café felt obliged to grant us a table with better light.

Eliot phoned on a Thursday when the bin lorry had already done its music. He asked me, in a voice that made him sound like he had slept and not slept, if I wanted to do an event in London in a fortnight. The pitch was a conversation rather than a cage match; the venue was an old cinema with seats that had held very many hearts through very many films. “We could be grown-ups,” he said, and it was both a promise and a dare. I thought of the wire between us and how it had been, suddenly, less taut. I thought of the part of me that is a medieval peasant and looks for omens in the tea leaves and the part of me that is a man who has learned to wind a watch and let it tick. I told him to send me the details and that I would ask Clemency to look at the contract so we would not accidentally sell our pasts to a drinks brand. He laughed, relieved, as if the negotiation were a language he was glad we shared, and when we hung up I stood at the window and watched a woman teach a toddler to kick a ball and wished all our lessons were conducted with that kind of weather.

On the day the pamphlet was agreed in principle, I went to the charity shop with the haunted sequinned dress and found, tucked into a pile of things that had once been vital to someone, a jacket that looked like the cousin of the one Clemency had made me wear. It had elbow patches and a smell that said its previous owner had not been unkind. I paid three pounds and the woman at the till told me that I was the man from the television and that her husband had held her hand through my piece without even looking, which was the politest thing he had done in a month. I wore the jacket out and went to the Cathedral Green and sat on the grass and wrote the first paragraph of something I did not yet have a name for, and thought: this is what it is to begin, again, and again.

At home, the post had one of those brown envelopes that make even the innocent feel guilty. It was from the show, a royalties statement that looked like a list of everything I didn’t know about the world. Tucked inside was a printed photograph, glossy in that way that makes fingers leave proof of themselves, of me on the stage at the moment my mouth was closed and the light had not yet decided. Someone had written on the back, in a hand I did not recognise but trusted immediately, Thank you for making the small things large. Don’t tell my boss, I cried during a light-check. I put it on the fridge next to the picture of my shoulder relaxed because it seemed right that my shoulder should have company.

A week later, at the event in the old cinema, Eliot and I learned how to be near each other without taking something that was not offered. The chairs were misbehaving and the microphones had a static crackle like old stars confessing, and the audience were the kind of people who have learned to clap without being told when to. We spoke about the difference between performance and hospitality and how sometimes the worst thing you can do to a feeling is put a bow on it. He said something generous about the way my work invites people to be better to themselves, and I said something true about the way his refuses to let anyone, including him, keep their comfortable lies. There were laughs and there were sighs and there were a few weaponised questions from the floor which we parried not with swords but with small domestic tools. In the bar after, he stood with his back to a poster for an old war film and told me that when he was nineteen he had wanted to be applauded for his cruelty and now he wanted to be applauded for his mercy and he was finding the second applause harder to earn. I told him mercy is harder to perform without props. We were quiet for a moment like men waiting for a kettle to click, and then he asked if I liked fennel yet and I told him I was trying.

On the train back that night, the carriage was full of people who had been to a different event involving sweat and lights and who were carrying their glitter home on their shoulders like a harmless contagion. I took the fountain pen out and wrote a list of the next small things I could do that would add up to a life: buy stamps; write back to the man in Parc; go to the allotments with tea in a flask and ask the man with the runner beans if he needed a hand; take my mother to the sea and let her point at boats and invent their biographies. At Tiverton Parkway, a man got on with a bag full of mushrooms and the certainty of his own intentions. The night outside the window was black and full and asked nothing of me but to arrive while it existed.

When I stepped through my own front door, the flat patted itself to show me everything was where I had left it. The plant I had not killed drew its leaves in like a person shivering dramatically for effect. The watch on the desk ticked with the kind of optimism that pretends to be ordinary. I put the new jacket on the back of the chair and the old jacket in the wardrobe and the photograph on the fridge under a magnet shaped like a sardine. Before bed, I set the alarm and then set the alarm inside my head, the one that says: when the mist is on the river, go and look. I slept and dreamt about a cupboard full of mugs none of which matched and all of which insisted on being exactly themselves, and in the morning the bells did not sulk at all. They sang like they had always known we were listening.Chapter Five

The week turned itself like a pillow and came up cool on the other side. Exeter changed gear without checking its mirrors and suddenly we were halfway to July and the evenings pretended they had no curfew. I woke to the sound of gulls who had discovered a new way to disagree about bread, and the cathedral, moody as a teenager asked to empty the dishwasher, decided she might forgive us today. There is a particular blue the river keeps for mornings when you needed to be told you can start again; it’s the colour of metal left out in kindness. I made tea and, because I have decided to behave like a person who owns his own life, I did not look at my phone until after the kettle had spoken twice.

Clemency sent a schedule in which my name looked like it had got on the wrong train. There was a daytime radio slot that would require my best vowels at an hour when my face still believes in darkness, and a meeting at the small publisher with the brooch in the shape of a question mark. She’d typed, with the smug affection of a woman who has shepherded worse beasts than me, that she had said no to two brand “opportunities,” one involving an insurance company’s campaign about braver home contents and one involving a cereal bar. “If you need more fibre,” she added, “we can attend to that without money changing hands.” I sent her a photograph of my porridge as tribute and she replied with a thumbnail of her shoes, which is her way of reminding me she is very good at walking briskly towards my better interests.

On Wednesday the school wrote, the one where I had sat through assemblies about road safety that made death sound both efficient and moral. The email came via a woman called Dawn with decades of competence in her sentences and an attachment called “SpeechDayRunningOrderFINALFINAL2.docx.” They were short of someone who could tell a roomful of teenagers that life had a shape without lying to them. Would I speak for seven minutes about writing and not giving up and, possibly, resilience, but only if I actually meant it. I read the word “resilience” and pictured a shop selling “Resilience!” in small boxes next to the till. I wrote back that I would say what I could say without causing anyone to doze upright. Dawn replied within ten minutes with three exclamation marks and a line about biscuits. I put the date in my calendar and touched wood and my pocket and the top of the doorframe on my way out of the kitchen because superstition is, for me, a form of stretching.

The publisher’s office was the sort of small room in which it is possible to believe you could make a book with your hands. There were boxes that looked heavy in a way that makes you want to be useful, and a potted plant that was thriving out of sheer bloody-mindedness. The woman with the brooch, whose name I really ought to have asked the first time and now could not, debriefed me over a biscuit that flaked like a veteran. “We’ve been thinking,” she said, which is a sentence that sets off the sprinklers in my head. “The pamphlet. A dozen pieces. Yours aren’t quite poems and they’re not quite essays and we’re not sorry about that. A small thing that fits a coat pocket and can be given to a person on a bench. We’ve mocked up covers.” She laid out three options like shirts before a wedding. One was a blue that felt slightly dishonest. One was a green that would take a bad photograph. One was exactly the colour of the river when it had decided to help. The title was our argument. “Not What You Win” had the plainness I admire and fear. “The Good Mugs” made me sentimental in a way the internet would punish me for. “Kindness Will Not Save Us” had the right fight but the wrong rhythm. In the end we did that British thing where we didn’t decide, and instead we made tea and agreed to live with our indecision for a week in the hope it would resolve itself overnight.

I walked from the office to the station because London reminds you that your body was designed to move in places where taxis can’t. On the train, a man slept with his mouth open and the confidence of someone who has never woken up on television with his own face on a nearby screen. Opposite me a girl annotated a textbook with the hand of a person teaching herself to forgive her sentences. The clouds over Woking organised themselves politely into ranks. I wrote half a paragraph about the way stations pretend to be beginnings when they are mostly middles. The woman who checked our tickets asked for mine like she was asking my name for the second time at a party and we both decided to pretend we remembered.

At the radio station they led me into a room that was both a cupboard and a spaceship. The producer was thirty and had the deep calm of a person who routinely shepherds panic into sound. He told me that we were going to talk about the rhythm of sadness and how to time a laugh so it works on the radio and then, without moving any of his muscles, asked me if I had ever been so angry I had bitten something that wasn’t food. We talked for twelve minutes about fathers without saying the word “grief” once and then, after the red light had politely put itself to bed, he asked me to sign a staff mug. “We break them on Thursday afternoons,” he explained. “It looks unprofessional if it’s one of the expensive ones.” I wrote, “Do not put this in the dishwasher,” and then stood with the pen above the ceramic for a heartbeat and added, “Be kind to the person who washes it.”

Afterwards, I sat on a bench in Embankment Gardens and watched a pigeon perform despair with a level of commitment that made it not only believable but briefly fashionable. A woman in running kit did the sort of stretching that makes strangers feel tired, and a man in a suit that had known better days ate a ham sandwich with the gravity of a priest. I phoned my mother and told her the radio had gone well and yes, of course she could listen back on the internet and no, she didn’t need to call Linda because Linda had already left a voicemail asking if I could get her Mixtape Man from the weekend following the one we were talking about to do a shout-out for her cat. “You sound thin,” my mother said, which is her way of asking if I am eating. I told her about the biscuits and she was satisfied in the way only carbohydrates can satisfy someone’s mother at two in the afternoon.

Back in Exeter that evening the river pretended it had been waiting for me specifically, which is the sort of lie I am happy to be told. Imogen had chalk dust on her nose and contempt for someone who had asked for iced coffee as if Britain had always been a place that did that. I sat in the window and tried on possible lives in the reflection. In one of them I lived in London again, wore a better jacket, ran for trains with resentment, pretended it didn’t matter who was in the room. In one of them I moved to a village with a pub that gave you change in coins that felt like old prayers, and I wrote in a wooden chair that had injured men for a century, and I sometimes forgot to be terrified. In the actual life I drank coffee that had been made by someone who refuses to spell my name correctly on principle, and I cut a paragraph that tried too hard, and I put the paragraph on a small pile called “Keep for later,” which is mostly a compost heap with delusions of grandeur.

The letter from Parc turned into a parcel. It arrived on a Thursday afternoon smelling of permanent marker and patience. Inside there were pages in the careful hand of a man not writing to impress anyone, a list of the small tasks he had set himself: peel an orange in one motion, count the steps from cell to chapel without making it look like you are counting, learn the names of the birds that will come if you put crumbs on the windowsill and pretend you didn’t mean it. There was a drawing of a mug with “GOOD” written on it, done in biro with a dedication to a man who had never been allowed to choose a mug in his life.
