Imogen had chalk dust on her nose and contempt for someone who had asked for iced coffee as if Britain had always been a place that did that. I sat in the window and tried on possible lives in the reflection. In one of them I lived in London again, wore a better jacket, ran for trains with resentment, pretended it didn’t matter who was in the room. In one of them I moved to a village with a pub that gave you change in coins that felt like old prayers, and I wrote in a wooden chair that had injured men for a century, and I sometimes forgot to be terrified. In the actual life I drank coffee that had been made by someone who refuses to spell my name correctly on principle, and I cut a paragraph that tried too hard, and I put the paragraph on a small pile called “Keep for later,” which is mostly a compost heap with delusions of grandeur.

The letter from Parc turned into a parcel. It arrived on a Thursday afternoon smelling of permanent marker and patience. Inside there were pages in the careful hand of a man not writing to impress anyone, a list of the small tasks he had set himself: peel an orange in one motion, count the steps from cell to chapel without making it look like you are counting, learn the names of the birds that will come if you put crumbs on the windowsill and pretend you didn’t mean it. There was a drawing of a mug with “GOOD” written on it, done in biro with a dedication to a man who had never been allowed to choose a mug in his life. There was permission from the governor and a timetable with my name in a column called “VISITING EDUCATORS” that made me feel briefly like a person with a backpack full of felt tips and a purpose. “If you will,” he had written in the space under “Activities”, “tell the men that even if there is nothing to be done, there are things to do.” I emailed Clemency and she said that she would navigate the forms and that I should buy a belt that would not set off the scanner and that she would remind me, gently but relentlessly, that a workshop is a workshop and not an attempt to un-make the world.

Speech Day came dressed in bunting and rain that couldn’t commit. The hall was how I remembered it and also smaller, because time is rude. The headteacher had the polished kindness of a man who has broken up fights by remembering boys’ names. A child in a blazer sat at the piano and played something that was trying to be Beethoven and landed instead in the soft field of “very nearly.” I sat on a plastic chair that had not forgiven anyone who had ever been late. When it was my turn, the microphone was both too close and too far and the floor was waxed in a way that made menace elegant. I looked at the faces of thirteen-year-olds who have learned already to hide their catastrophes and the faces of seventeen-year-olds who think they have invented every feeling. I told them I had scribbled my name on the underside of this very chair with a compass because I was bored and then spent the next year petrified my handwriting would give me away. I asked them, because I can’t help myself, what was the strangest thing they had ever believed about themselves, and I held the silence at the end of the question like a bowl for their answers. A girl in the third row said she had believed for a whole year that she was bad at reading because she read quickly, and a boy in a tie he had not tied himself said he had believed he was supposed to be the one who was always fine and now he wasn’t sure what the question even meant. Somewhere near the back, a boy with the eyes of a creature that knows which bushes the foxes favour looked at me and then looked away as if I had looked at him in a language he had not yet learned to understand. I told them that when I was thirteen I thought being ordinary was the worst thing, and that at thirty-seven I considered it the rescue boat. A few teachers laughed in the guilty way adults laugh when they recognise themselves. The headteacher shook my hand afterwards and thanked me for being ordinary on purpose in front of his pupils and offered me one of those biscuits that taste of fundraising and starch.

In my mother’s kitchen that afternoon the smell was of onion and decision. She had written “SPAG BOL” on a piece of paper as if it were a spell that needed stroking into being. The radio told us about a by-election in a voice that refused to admit it hoped for chaos, and she told me that Aunt Joy had found a dance class for women with opinions and was coming home flushed twice a week with the joy of someone who had been allowed to sweat. I asked her if she still had Dad’s jumper, and she got up without asking me why and went to the cupboard where she keeps the things she pretends she doesn’t keep, and brought out the bag that once had apples in it. The jumper smelled like the ghost of a summer shed. She watched me smell it with the benign cruelty of a person who has been practicing not crying for longer than I’ve been alive. “He wrote things down,” she said, stirring the sauce with a wooden spoon that had never learned another job. “Not just lists. Bits and bobs. You know that.” I nodded. “He wrote bird names wrong on purpose,” she added, as if confessing to petty theft, “so you would correct him and you would learn them without feeling like someone was putting facts in you. He said it made you fierce in a way he liked. He kept them all.” She went to the dresser and brought me a notebook with a fat elastic band in the middle and his careful untidy handwriting at the top of the first page: “Blakbird, Robin, Tosspot Tit.” I laughed with my whole face and then in the crease of the laugh there was the ache, and that was alright. We ate spaghetti and she told me, guarded and open, how he had once nearly auditioned for the village pantomime as a cow and had backed out because he did not want to look like the man who always said yes, and how he had regretted it and then made the allotment the place where he said yes to everything else.

The workshop at Parc required shoes you couldn’t run in and a willingness to hand over your essentials to a locker that smelled, faintly, of older versions of hope. The security guards were both bored and heroic, and the metal detector was a child performing attention. The officer who escorted me through had a voice that would have served him well in church and a wrist tattoo that did not. In the classroom the tables were laid out in a horseshoe, which is a shape that makes adults behave better. The men came in with their shoulders already braced for embarrassment and their eyes already occupied elsewhere. The man who had written to me sat down and tapped the table twice with his nail because his hands needed work. I told them we would be writing lists and that I would not be confiscating any of them, and the man at the back with the beautifully ridiculous ears said thank Christ, which I chose to interpret as enthusiasm. We did the work of making it safe to say something without pretending it was safe here. They wrote “Ten small mercies you can make with your hands” and “Five facts you didn’t know were true until you told them to someone else.” One of them wrote that he was good at polishing shoes to the point where they resembled their own dreams of themselves and that when he got out he wanted to be paid for making other people feel ready to meet their days. One of them wrote that he knew how to fold sheets with military corners and that it might be the only useful thing he had learned in a place designed to teach you all the wrong lessons. They asked me about the television and I told them it was a machine that kept working whether you wanted it to or not, and that the only part of it that had felt like home was the part where I said what I had to say. At the end, the man who had written me the mug drew me a watch in biro, complete with a tiny second hand moving nowhere in particular, and labelled it “to be wound.”

It was on the way back from Parc that Eliot phoned, and the Welsh hills executed their performance of looking like a late apology. “Are you at a service station?” he said, and he said it with such elegant disdain for service stations that I had to pull over just to give the moment the attention it deserved. He was in a taxi that was taking too long and he wanted to complain artistically. “I did the thing last night,” he said, not naming which thing because there is only ever one thing and it’s always the most. “I said a line and I thought of you saying the other line and I wondered if we were writing into each other’s blanks.” There was a horn and a sigh. “Can I come down,” he asked without being the kind of person who asks, “and read with you above the bicycle shop and then be humbled by your scones?” I told him that the scones were not mine to deploy but that I would speak to the appropriate authorities. When I told Ollie he made a noise like a kettle that has decided not to boil and then he made a poster with only initials and a picture of a bicycle whose wheels were made of punctuation. “Nobody needs this,” he said, cheerfully lying, “and therefore it will be good.”

We took my mother to the sea on a Saturday that had remembered what Saturdays are for. Dawlish was in the mood to please, throwing a train along the edge of itself like a trick it never gets bored of. We bought chips so hot they made us walk like injured birds. A gull the size of a possible sin hovered above my mother’s head with the entitlement of a landlord, and she waved it away with the hand of a woman who has taught bigger creatures their manners. She told me, because she always gets around to saying the thing she has come to say, that she had found a letter in the shed, addressed to “R + M” in my father’s unsteady pretence at a copperplate. Inside was a list of the things he could do if he had to leave earlier than he wanted. “Put the watch in the drawer for a while,” it said, “and don’t you dare throw out the fork. The beans need it. Rowan will say he hates performance and then he’ll get on a stage because he can’t stop himself telling the kitchen stories to strangers. Let him. He’ll come home.” My mother had underlined “He’ll come home” in two colours, because her extravagance is usually for other people, and she rolled her eyes at the idea of being predicted and then she cried with her mouth in that tidy way she has and let me see it. We sat on the sea wall and I could feel the day going to sleep under my hands, and it was the sort of tired that tells you you’ve earned it.

The reading with Eliot above the bicycle shop made the stair perform its party piece twice. People came because they had been told to be reasonable for too long and this did not look reasonable. The room was too warm and too thankful. Eliot wore black because he has never learned that Exeter does not care, and he looked at the fairy lights like a man being introduced to earnestness for the first time at a cousin’s wedding. We took turns and then we took risks and then we took questions from a corner where someone had brought a baby who gurgled when we said the word “kind.” He read the orange again and let it have more juice this time, and I read something about the hardware shop where the man behind the counter always says, “We can sort you out,” as if that were a vow and not a sales technique. When the questions bent themselves into weapons, we set them down gently and asked the askers if they were alright. Afterward, he stood on the pavement and tried to light a cigarette in a wind that knew better, and I stood next to him with a bag of Imogen’s scones and we performed détente with crumbs. He said, and I could feel the sentence rough its way over his teeth, that he had been shown a picture of himself at nineteen and had not found it useful, and that perhaps he needed a picture of himself at forty with his mouth closed. I told him that mouths are difficult, and he laughed with relief like a man putting down a small heavy box. He asked to see the river like a tourist and I took him to it like a local, and we leaned and did the man thing of pretending to be thinking about boats when we were really thinking about not drowning.

The day the pamphlet’s title decided itself, it did it while I was not in the room. I came home to an email from the question-mark brooch that said, “We’re all pretending this was your idea. ‘Not What You Win.’ Font attached. There will be an argument about staples on Tuesday.” The cover was the river colour and the paper had that roughness that makes a reader feel they are permitted to touch. I held the PDF up to the light as if it might develop like a photograph. The list of contents made me feel both organised and exposed. I wrote back my agreed-upon yes and then walked to the allotments with a flask because there is no celebration like watching someone water beans. The man with the runner beans was there, shoulders curved to the job like a blessing, and I handed him tea and he handed me string, and we built a frame that could teach you as much about performance as any stage. Tension and give, resistance and the refusal to snap, the memory a knot keeps of the hands that tied it. He told me, in the unpunctuated way people talk when they are doing something they understand, about his grandsons and the tomatoes they grew on a windowsill and how the window sill had got into the tomatoes. I listened, which is to say I let him not ask a question and still expect an answer. When I left he said, “Mind how you go,” and it felt like a benediction rather than an instruction.

In August the swifts left in the middle of a sentence and the river lost its gossip. School uniforms appeared in shop windows like an apology. The bicycle shop put up a sign about repairing punctures and broken hearts and Ollie pretended he hadn’t done it and then took the credit when asked. The pamphlet proofs arrived in a cardboard envelope that sounded important when opened. I sat at the table with a pencil and did the religious work of making small black marks on a future. I changed “and” to “but” and then back again as if the conjunction were a life choice. I called my mother to ask if she wanted the dedication or if that would create more trouble than it solved, and she said that she wanted to be on the acknowledgements in small print because she is not a show-off, but that if I put Aunt Joy on the acknowledgements I had to let her choose her own comma. I wrote, “For M., for R., for the cupboard with the good mugs,” and I stopped while I was still being honest.

At the launch, which was a jug of wine, a jug of water and a table that had seen more ambitious nights, people queued to have me write their names on paper like it meant anything. A woman who had seen me on the television and then avoided her sadness for two months and then failed to avoid it the following Tuesday asked me to write, “You are not what you win,” and I did, and she pressed the book to her stomach like a baby and I did not show off by being clever. The man from Parc’s wife came without telling me she would and held my hand for long enough that the part of me that hates being held had to shut up. Eliot sent flowers wrapped in brown paper that made them look earnest, and a card that said, “This is not a concession,” which is his romance. Imogen refused to let me pay for the traybakes and Ollie did a speech that pretended to be a joke and was, in truth, a stitch in something that might hold.

After the people, after the photographs in which my shoulder is again, miraculously, relaxed, after the tinny clink of glasses that revealed themselves to be plastic, I walked home through a city that had finally let its hair down. I passed the charity shop window where the sequinned dress had given up its mystery to a woman who was taking it somewhere it deserved. I passed the second-hand bookshop that smelled of ambitions that had been well loved. At the bridge I leaned the way men have always leaned and I wound the watch in my pocket because some habits are more honest than prayer. The bells did not sulk. The swifts were gone and the sky had put the kettle on for the long boil of autumn. The pamphlet lay in my bag, the good mugs waited in their cupboard, Exeter kept its gossip to itself, and I went upstairs to the flat that had forgiven me, and I slept under the comfortable weight of a day that had not tried to turn itself into a headline.

Chapter Seven

By September the swifts had packed their tiny bags and left without forwarding addresses, and the river went back to telling slower stories. The city began that annual rehearsal for weather, finding scarves at the backs of drawers like old loyalties and pretending we had always known how to stand still and be rained on with dignity. I woke one morning to a sky the colour of kitchen foil and the sound of the council’s leaf blower insisting autumn was a structural fault that could be remedied by enthusiasm. The watch on my desk ticked with the equanimity of a small god. I had not learned to be equanimous, but I had learned to wind.

The pamphlet did what small books do when they are allowed to leave the house. It went into the world in coat pockets and handbags and once, according to a photograph sent by a woman called Shauna from Paisley, into the hollow of a radiator where it sat for two days like a guilty child until the central heating admitted defeat and gave it back. People wrote to say they had read it on a lunch break and then gone back to their desks with their shoulders lowered by one stubborn inch. A man in Leeds posted it to his brother in Ballinasloe with a note that said, “You don’t have to like poems,” and then wrote to me in a panic to ask if it was, in fact, a poem, because he feared he had lied. A woman in Birmingham asked if I would sign three copies to “Saira, who has fought and won, Kay, who is still fighting, and Mum, who says she never fought anyone but lies beautifully.” The small publisher sent me an email with the subject line “Reprint?” and the question mark did a small dance in my stomach I tried to ignore and then welcomed like a proper guest.

It turns out if you say “not what you win” out loud in public enough times, people assume you are the sort of person who is immune to prizes and the weather. I am not immune to either. The first time a list appeared with my name on it I felt the old wire tighten in the room, the one that attaches me to the version of myself who believes affection is a ration and whoever gets the largest tin has eaten yours. The list was for a prize with a name that sounds like a piece of furniture, and the email came from a literary administrator who has never left a kettle unattended in her life. Clemency phoned before I could forward it to her and said, warmly but strictly, that I was to say “thank you” in three places and not be caught in a photograph trying to disappear into my own jacket. “This is not a night for humility you wear like borrowed shoes,” she said. “You will eat the canapés instead of taking them for a walk. Also, wear the river-colour tie.”

I wore the tie because it looked like somebody had bottled a good day. The event was in a room that had hosted enough ceremonies to believe itself a church, which is to say there were chairs and opinions. Eliot was there with his coat the colour of a decision and a smile that revealed nothing about the rest of him. He waved like a diplomat from a friendly but distant country. The man from the big paper asked if he could write a profile and the woman from the radio promised me three minutes on a Friday if I could make grief witty. I smiled in a way my face recognised as survival and watched several conversations in which I starred glide past like swans that would not let me feed them. The winner was someone I liked in print and in person, which is a relief and also a fresh challenge for my pettier self. On the train home I balanced the certificate on my knees and texted my mother a photograph; she wrote back, This is the nice paper, and attached a small string of party hat emojis that looked like a regiment of festive carrots.

It was after that night that the paper ran their profile anyway, as papers will, with a picture of me looking like I’d been told to imagine a joke about someone else. The headline contained the word “reluctant,” which is the lazy shorthand people use when a person’s face refuses to arrange itself into uninterrupted ambition. The journalist had been to Exeter and asked me about the river and my father and the cupboard with the good mugs, and I had answered in the only way I know, which is to tell the truth and then tidy it as if it were late for something. When the piece appeared, the quotes were accurate and the adjectives were not, and it included a paragraph about how I “had not married my work” that made me sound like a man who had jilted a profession at the altar and fled to Devon with grief on the back of a moped. Imogen read it with the expression she reserves for weather forecasts and break-up songs, rolled her eyes so thoroughly she nearly saw her own thought processes, and drew a moustache on my newsprint face with legitimate skill. “You look better,” she said, handing it back, and then put it under the grinder to stop it from floating around my head like a wasp.

Meanwhile my mother decided the shed had had long enough to sulk and needed to be helped into its next life. The allotment committee, who are a body composed of men with twine and verdicts, had offered me my father’s plot on condition that I sign a form promising never to grow more than a patriotic proportion of courgettes. “It’s time,” my mother said in the voice she used when I was six and had hidden my school shoes under my bed in protest at the concept of walking as a public act. We went down on a Saturday that had decided to be generous and found the fork where it had always leant, a vertical memorial that did not make a fuss. The shed smelled like my father’s pockets, which is to say, a small kingdom of twine and pencils and the tobacco he didn’t smoke anymore except in habits. We emptied boxes that had kept themselves busy by shifting their contents from one corner to another when left alone. There were seed packets that had decided to retire and a tin of screws that looked exactly like a tin of screws and a jam jar full of coins from three currencies and a decade. There were notebooks with my father’s handwriting practising its untidiness and a page headed “Things to Mend,” under which he had written “Fence, gate, attitude (Rowan’s), patience (mine).”

Under a stack of plant pots we found a shoe box with three cassettes in it, labelled in that careful not-careful hand: “Birds 1998”, “To M”, and “R—Don’t be cross.” My mother took the one with her letter and put it in her pocket as if it had heat, and I took mine and did not put it near my heart because I am sentimental about too many other things as it is. We no longer own a device for the purpose, because time is impolite, but Linda from down the road does, because Linda has never met a gadget she didn’t store for later. She set it up on her kitchen table between a fruit bowl the shape of regret and a small army of porcelain hedgehogs, and we pressed play knowing we had not prepared enough for the sound of a man we loved arriving in the room. At first there was only tape hiss, the radio static of the past making itself at home, and then my father cleared his throat in that way he used to, as if giving the air a chance to behave.

“Right,” he said, and then laughed at himself for saying right to nobody. “Rowan. If you’re listening to this, first of all, your mother hasn’t thrown out my old tape recorder, which is a victory for my side. Second of all, I am about to say some things I am not clever enough to write down because then I’ll fiddle with the words instead of telling you what I mean.” He proceeded to misname birds for seven minutes in a row with such deliberate wrongness I laughed and then had to put my hand over my mouth because of the sound trying to get out. “Blakbird. Robbin. Angry Poet Tit.” Between jokes, he fitted in the sentences I had wanted and the ones I had not known I wanted. He told me to be common as muck in my kindness and fancy as I liked in my sentences. He told me to wind the watch when I needed the day to have a spine. He told me that if I ever felt like I was losing, to check whether I had started counting the wrong things. When the tape clicked off Linda and my mother and I sat there as if we had been told not to move during a wasp, and Linda broke the spell by putting a plate of biscuits in front of us because she is a magician who uses sugar as her wand.

I took the allotment because it would have been rude not to. The first time I put the fork into the earth and leaned, I remembered the choreography of it in my bones like a song I hadn’t liked at the time and now found myself humming. The soil gave up its stones with that reluctant generosity dirt displays when it likes you. The man with the runner beans watched me from his side of the thin wire civilization and nodded as if to say I had not ruined anything yet. He came over with string and a suggestion about wind and we built another frame, this time with ghost hands helping. In the afternoons I would take my pages down there and read a paragraph to the path between the beds, because I have decided there is no point in pretending not to be the man who talks to dirt. When I looked up, there were always the gulls doing philosophy at the sky and the small children doing philosophy at the puddles, and somehow the arguments overlapped.

The prison wrote to ask if I could come back and bring, if possible, more lists. The men had found the business of naming mercies a tolerable way to spend a Tuesday, and one of them had started a thing he called “The Cupboard,” which was a list on the wall in the education block of items to try when the day was behaving like a locked door. It included “learn the names of the people who clean your cell and say them like they’re worth knowing,” and “remember your favourite word, not the one you should like, the one you do,” and “what to do with an orange when there is no knife,” which I suspect he wrote to make me laugh. The governor had given cautious permission for the small publisher to print fifty copies of a zine we were calling “The Good Mugs,” and the brooch editor had cried on the phone for a bit, then cleared her throat, then asked me for names to put in the back under “Made by,” and I did my best to do no harm. On my second visit, the man with the ridiculous ears read aloud a list called “Reasons I Did Not Hit Him Back” and it was so beautiful and so ferocious in its refusal to make a saint out of himself that the room stood up in the way rooms sometimes do when no one told them to.

It was after that workshop that Eliot came down on a weekday and tried to pretend he did not care about trains. He arrived at St David’s in a coat that had not been tested for drizzle and a face that had recently done a fight with a mirror and called it grooming. He looked around as if cities are actors who can remember their lines if prompted. “This whole place,” he said, “feels like a good sentence you’ve taken an axe to in the right places.” I took him to the café where Imogen refused to be impressed on principle and then, when he said the words “single origin” without performing a somersault, allowed him to exist. We walked by the river and he refused, out of stubbornness and fear of cliché, to say “pretty,” and we talked about work in the way men do when they are trying not to show underbellies. He confessed he had said no to a television thing that would have made him the man who says yes to all the things, and I told him I had said no to cereal bars, and we stood there being faintly heroic about not selling ourselves for oat flakes. It was only later he admitted it felt more like relief than courage.

We read again above the bicycle shop because Ollie announced we would and then had the terrible luck of being right. The poster this time was just a picture of the river and a pencil with a halo, and when Eliot saw it he said he had always suspected the West Country of being better at piety. The room was full of people who had decided they liked the sensation of concentrating together and a few who had come because they had resolved, in a valiant way, to start liking poetry by force. Eliot read a piece about shame that did the precise unkindness required to be merciful, and I read a list called “Instructions for the Ordinary Day” that included “make tea in a mug someone else would choose,” and “call your mother and ask about one thing she could have been champion of,” and “find a faintly ridiculous bird and applaud it.” At the end an old man with hair like a memory came up and told us the story of when he had been nineteen and had all his money stolen by a woman he later married, and we listened for long enough that the listening turned into a kind of love.

The invitation to the school’s winter fair arrived on a postcard with a snowman who looked like he’d had to reapply for his job. Could I judge mince pies without hurting anyone and would I be willing to read something at the turning on of the lights that would not cause children to ask awkward questions about mortality. I said yes to the pies and maybe to the reading, and then spent an afternoon trying to write a sentence in which a fairy light has a crisis of faith and still gets turned on without anything tragic happening to it. On the day, I stood in a gym that smelled of wax and teenage bravery and tasted thirty-two pies and learned both the limits to human cinnamon tolerance and the thrill of being permitted to wield a score sheet. A child in a homemade elf hat asked me if I was the man who had been on the television and whether I could tell his dad that it is allowed to cry when you watch adverts; I told him that I could tell his dad and that his dad would agree but would phrase it in a way that made it sound like he had invented the concept.

Clemency arranged a small tour of bookshops that were really rooms with good lighting and excellent chairs. We did Bristol on a Tuesday to an audience that included a man who knows the difference between “affect” and “effect” and will speak up about it if provoked, and we did Bath to a roomful of women who knit during questions and then produced more insight than anyone else in Britain. We did Truro to a man who had driven two hours to be told it was OK to love a thing from the late 90s sincerely. On the train between cities I wrote a piece about what to pack if you plan to be generous, and it included “a pen that doesn’t explode under pressure,” and “coins,” and “a cardigan with pockets that can pretend to be a hug,” and “a story about your worst mistake told without self-deprecation,” and I read it in Falmouth to a woman who came up afterwards and said she had been waiting thirty-seven years to be told to stop making her own pain charming.

In November the river pumped itself with a kind of purpose that felt like news. The allotment went to sleep with the severity of a child refusing to be convinced. I planted garlic because Eliot told me it made you feel like you were doing something about the future, and I put my hand to the ground and it felt like a chest still breathing. My mother began her annual campaign to pretend Christmas did not require planning while simultaneously planning Christmas with a military precision that would have impressed even the most annoying head of year. Aunt Joy took up tap, which none of us deserved but all of us enjoyed, and Linda’s cat found a new way to look offended by tinsel. I wound the watch and let it tick through the early dark like an argument for patience.

It was around then that the email came from the school saying a boy in Year Ten had asked if I would look at his poem, and would I tell him, gently, whether it was good because otherwise he would measure himself by silence and that was not fair. His name was Isaac and he wrote like a person who had overheard a good conversation and knew he was supposed to lean in. He wrote, “I am not the boy you think is fine, I am the boy who knows where the foxes go,” and when I read it I put the piece of paper down and breathed like a sensible person, which in my case is a novelty. I wrote back that he had made something with a shape and a sound and that he should write twenty more, not because he had to prove anything to anyone, but because he had found something that made one minute pay attention to the next. He sent a second poem three days later called “List of Quiet,” and I put it on my fridge next to my own photograph because one of us had to be in good company.

The call from the London programme came as the river was trying to be a mirror and failing in an honorable way. They wanted a Christmas show full of “heart” and “light,” and the producer used the word “uplift” twice in one sentence and I watched my better self try not to stand up and walk out of my body. Clemency did our layers of honesty and determined there was room for me to do a thing that would not make me look like a man delivering parsnips to a nation from a sleigh. I wrote a piece called “Instructions for Christmas,” which included, “find somebody who hates it and make them a cheese toastie,” and “remember your dead by telling a good joke they would have laughed at,” and “do not attempt to reform your entire personality by Boxing Day,” and “put one mug at the back of the cupboard and call it January.” On the night, I wore the jacket with elbow patches that smelled like its previous owner chopped wood and sang and I did not say “bugger,” and the studio made that fond noise it makes when it is pretending it is your living room. After, a woman stopped me at the station and told me her brother had died in February and that she had laughed at the bit with the toastie and she thought he would have loved it because he always burned everything and smiled about it. I stood there like a man confronted by mercy in a queue and promised myself, again, I would count the right things.

On the last day of the year, I went to the allotment with a flask and a notebook and the sort of optimism that leaves the door open for realism to come back in later. The beds were tart with cold and the path pretended to be an ice rink you could skate on with your eyes. The fork leaned and the shed stood and the world agreed to be bigger than my little life by at least the correct margin. I wrote a list of ten ways to enter a year and I did not number them because some things are not ranking exercises. It said, “wind the watch,” and “bring your own light but let other people hold it,” and “ask the river what it knows and pretend to understand,” and “rescue one ridiculous thing and let it rescue you back.” On the way home I saw a boy practicing keepy-uppies against a wall with the air of a surgeon and a girl in an enormous coat teaching a dog how to take off a mitten gently, and I put both of them in my pocket for later.

At midnight the cathedral did not sulk at all. She sang herself inside out, and the city shouted responses in the language of pans banging and fireworks admitting defeat to clouds. I stood at my window with a mug that did not match any other mug and watched Exeter remember and forget itself in the exact right proportions. My phone sulked on the table and then behaved and then sulked, and I let it because we were both tired. I thought of the men at Parc, forty seconds into a new year they had to spend the same way they had spent the last one and the next one, and I promised myself a morning in January for “The Cupboard.” I thought of Isaac, and the poem about foxes, and my father’s voice misnaming birds on purpose, and my mother’s face when she tasted a mince pie she had not made and declared it brave. I wound the watch, listened to the tick settle into the dark like a metronome for a heart, and went to bed in a flat that had decided to forgive me again tomorrow if I asked nicely and brought coffee.

Chapter Eight

January arrived as if it had been waiting outside the door with its boots on, pretending not to mind the cold. The river gave up its gossip and dealt in facts; frost wrote its arguments along the bins with a thoroughness I respected. I woke to a morning so bright and pitiless it made even the cathedral look freshly washed, and I did the thing that has become my compromise with the day: kettle on, blinds open, watch wound. It is hard to overstate the comfort of a small machine choosing, politely and without grandeur, to behave again when asked. The first week the city looked like it had stopped breathing by accident and needed reminding, the way you put a hand to a sleeping dog to be sure. We remembered our scarves and the gulls remembered their right to be indignant, and the council trucks performed a ballet along the quay involving grit, hand signals and the kind of mutual trust I associate with marriages where nobody posts about it.

I kept my promise to Parc the second Tuesday, the one the governor had offered me cautiously, as if kindness was a resource he was not quite prepared to believe could be replenished. I learned the system well enough to move through it without insulting it: belt off, watch in the tray, palms up, questions answered in the tone that tells a person you know they are not the one who designed the rules. The corridor smelled of floor polish and the tiredness of men who have learned to stand still. In the classroom the horseshoe of tables was waiting again like a tool that had made itself useful and resented it slightly. The men came in as men do when their names have been said too loudly for too long. This time I brought a list with me, which is to say I brought a way to bring them to the table without making them present their throats. “The Cupboard,” I wrote on the whiteboard, and underneath it, in my careful teacher hand, because that is the role I can fill without lying: “Things to do when there is nothing to be done.”

We made it together, which is the only way I know to honour the fiction that we were not pretending at anything else. “Learn the names of the rivets in the bunk,” offered the man with the ridiculous ears, and the room did that laugh it does when it has decided liking you is easier than distrusting you. “Fold a T-shirt more slowly than pride would allow,” said another, and a third contributed, in a voice two sizes too large for his sentence, “Write a postcard to the person you were nineteen, and forgive him for thinking he would never need to learn to cook rice.” The man who had started this with his letter held the pen like a tool he had just discovered had more than one function and wrote, deliberately, “Breathe into your hands until they stop being a weapon.” I stood there with the marker and nodded like a priest and the room let itself be church. In the break, the officer with the wrist tattoo asked me if I knew the poem about the people in the boats and the mouth and I said I did and he told me, with the kind of careful resentment people keep for the things that have hurt them into beauty, that he had once cried by a fence. When I left, the list stayed behind on the wall, and I tried not to imagine it being taken down and put in a folder marked “ARTS,” because imagining it there felt like a promise I wanted to keep.

The watch stopped on a Friday, exactly at midday, the hands lined up in a way that would have looked deliberate if I were a person inclined to read omens where there are only guts and gears. I put it to my ear and heard nothing and the quiet had weight. I do not need a watch in the way men used to; I live inside a machinery of notifications that will not allow me to die without an alarm. And yet the silence sent me into a small panic that felt exactly as serious as it needed to and no more. I asked around quietly, because Exeter is full of people who know exactly what you need if you ask in the tone that suggests you will not be a burden. A man with a stall on the market offered the name of a watchmaker in Topsham who, according to him, had fixed a clock that had decided to stop every year on the date a woman’s husband had died. “She made it behave kindly,” he said, with the reverence of a man who had had enough of depending on magic. I took the train along the river, the mudflats spread like an old argument and the boats looking embarrassed for ever having believed they were essential.

The watchmaker’s shop was not a shop so much as a room that had decided to remember its purpose after thinking about being a gallery. It smelled faintly of the kind of oil you only own if you own a screwdriver whose handle has grown glossy from use. Behind the counter sat a woman whose face had both kindness and a refusal to be hurried arranged on it in equal parts. She was Polish by the sound in her vowels and the anatomy of patience in her hands. “It runs,” she said, after I had told her my grandfather and the shed and my father’s stubbornness like a confession. “But it sulks. Hairspring…” She held it up to the light with the sort of tenderness you reserve for small animals and very old jokes. “It’s tired. We don’t replace tired. We polish it and we regulate it and we tell it the day is not an emergency.” She set it on a small cushion like a bed and listened to it with a stethoscope the size of a button. “You have wound it like you are sorry,” she said without looking up. “You’re allowed to wind it like you meant it. People do this,” she added, and tapped the bench lightly with a fingernail. “They think time will be offended.” She told me to come back Tuesday, which was to say, live a couple of days without insisting the past behave like a tool, and I went to the quay and watched the river thicken under a light that felt honest, and I went home and tried to be the sort of man who could use the oven without consulting the internet.

Imogen had stuck a hand-lettered sign in the café window that read, “January: we bake through it,” and underneath, in smaller writing, “Also the electricity bill has joined a gym and is very enthusiastic.” She had acquired a ceramic penguin from a charity shop, which she kept moving around the tables with the erratic logic of a woman giving herself a game in a month that punishes illusions. “It’s the size of a tiny baby and has the moral life of a teenager,” she said, when I asked, and then she told me the landlord had suggested that perhaps the market would bear a little adjustment, and we stood in the doorway and let January blow through us until the idea of bearing anything felt ludicrous. We ended up arranging a night called “Power To The Buns,” because neither of us has ever met a pun we did not regret and accept in the same motion. Ollie made a poster that featured a lightbulb eating a scone, which looked exactly wrong, and a list of names of people who would read, sing, or otherwise permit themselves to be seen in exchange for money put in a jar. I wrote copy for it that tried very hard not to be pity and landed somewhere closer to invitation: Come in out of the weather. We will warm you by proximity and pastry. Bring coins. Bring hands. Try to leave lighter than you arrived. If you cannot, we will send you away with cake.

The night was one of those that make you think we have been practicing for this our whole lives: standing in too-small rooms and making more air by listening. The fairy lights did their low work and the coffee machine tried not to interrupt at the wrong moments. Imogen refused to take the microphone and then, in the second half, told a story about a bus stop in Salcombe and a woman who cried into her gloves and the thunderous relief of being permitted to sit near a stranger who does not make you explain yourself. Ollie read a poem that admitted the existence of a sadness he had not previously given papers to and a girl of about sixteen sang like she had learned to be brave by mistake. At the end, when we counted the jar in the kitchen with the honesty of people who know exactly which coins are which, the sum was enough, not to save anything permanently, because we do not tell ourselves that kind of story here, but to give the month a spine and the bill a rival. Imogen wrote the number down on the back of a receipt as if it were a spell and stuck it under the penguin with a kind of private ecclesiastical satisfaction. When we walked home along the dark river the lamps threw coins across it as if bribing the water to keep behaving.

Eliot rang on a Wednesday and did not abbreviate it. He had that particular London quiet in his voice that means a person is alone in a room and is pretending their aloneness is a choice. “I have been offered a residency at a magazine,” he said, and I could hear the capital letters arranging themselves as they left his mouth. “It involves being in a glass box twice a week and being watched while I write in order to prove that writing happens and is not a trick. The money is insulting in both directions. The concept is… you can imagine.” I could. I could see him in a window where people buy linen, leaning on a sentence while a woman with a loyalty card wonders if she is supposed to clap. “They asked if I would consider inviting you,” he said, and somehow managed to make the word “inviting” sound like a long corridor. “We could be clever about it. We could burn the box down with tenderness. I could wear a paper crown. I could refuse to produce anything legible.” He laughed, and the laugh had the shape of a thing you keep until it either saves you or ruins your appetite.

I thought about it in the way I am learning to think, which is to ask myself if the story that would be told about it would be one I wanted to watch, and if the person I would be in that story is someone I would lend my mug to. “I don’t want to be watched while I’m not lying,” I said, eventually. “I already find it hard enough not to perform my honesty into a shape that suits. The box would be too much box.” There was a pause that was not offended and not entirely relieved. “Tell them you’re inventing a new residency,” I added. “Two chairs not facing each other, once a week, two writers who are not trying to win anything. We could do it in a library and leave the door ajar.” He exhaled in a way that sounded, for a second, like gratitude. “You’ve become unfashionable,” he said. “It’s very attractive.” We arranged a date for him to come down and, for the first time since the talent show announcement, I felt the wire between us behave like string, which is to say it learned give.

Isaac sent me a poem on a bad Thursday called “What to Do When the Foxes Choose Your Garden.” It began with the sound they make, described carefully and without drama, and proceeded to list instructions that would not fix anything and would make everything feel less like a verdict. “You could bang a pot,” he wrote, “but it won’t make them move any quicker, so wash it afterwards and think you’ve accomplished something.” He had learned the shape now, the way a sentence can curve its shoulder around the fragile thing it is carrying without dropping it. I asked him if he’d like to read at Power To The Buns in February and he wrote back that he would if he could bring his dad. I told him he could bring anyone who could stand and clap. When the night came, he stood next to the penguin in his school shoes and read four lines that made his father’s face perform that ancient trick of pretending something else is making your eyes behave like that. His father, afterwards, waited until Isaac had been congratulated by enough women with nice hair to survive a week, and then he came up to me like a man who had decided to ask a question and knew he would have to do it without bluster. “He wrote that,” he said, nodding at the space in which the poem had happened. “And my chest felt like… not panic. Not panic, but the cousin of it, who turns up without bringing a casserole. Is that what happens?” I said that sometimes it is exactly that and sometimes it is worse and sometimes it is the thing that will keep you from hitting someone who would later become a story you tell with unnecessary honesty. He nodded and did the British man thing of losing all his words at once and becoming grateful, and I told him he had done alright by breeding a boy who made a room behave.

The river came up one weekend in February the way it does every few years to remind us who owns this place. The boards went up along the quay with the speed of an old habit; the ducks looked offended on behalf of someone else. Imogen and I carried sacks as if we had been cast in a drama about resilience, and she shouted instructions at me using nouns I had never heard used like verbs outside a kitchen. People appeared with mops and sincere faces and the sort of camaraderie that flourishes best forty minutes into a catastrophe that is large enough to be meaningful and small enough to be contained. We moved chairs onto tables and tables onto counters and a child in a Spider-Man mask threaded himself through all of us doing his best to rescue things that were not strictly in peril. When the water pressed its forehead against the glass, pretending to consider coming in for coffee, I thought of how long I had lived thinking that weather was a thing that happened to other people while I arranged my sentences under kinder skies. After, when it retreated sulkily and left the smell of silt and relief, we scrubbed and laughed in the way that is not about joy but about endurance. Imogen refused to throw out the penguin because “he needs to see things,” and afterwards he looked different in a way only we could see.

The reprint of the pamphlet arrived with an email that had the subject line “We did the thing,” and a photograph of a pallet that looked like a giant’s idea of Christmas. The brooch editor wrote that bookshops were requesting twos and threes in a way that made her fond of humanity and then sent me a separate message that said, “A larger house asked if you’d like a proper book,” with a winky face, which is her way of placing a cushion between me and the furniture. Clemency and I sat at my table and drank coffee and she looked at me over her cup with the precise expression she uses for matters that could turn either into a feast or a migraine. “We can let them buy our dignity,” she said, “if we also make them buy you a jacket that is not a joke.” She laid out the arithmetic of it, the way she does when she thinks I will hide inside the complication to avoid making a decision: advances and rights and deadlines like polite teeth. I made lists in the column of my notebook that says “Things With Consequences,” and wrote under it: what will you have to rush, what will you teach yourself to hate, what will you get to carry that you could not have carried alone. In the end we did the thing we do, which is say yes as if it is the first time we have been asked, and write a clause about the cupboard with the good mugs. The brooch editor sent a congratulatory email that read, “We will be jealous admirably,” and I loved her in that moment like an aunt who knows when to arrive and when to leave.

My mother slipped on the step in her kitchen in late February and phoned not to report it but to ask if I had any spare plasters, which is our domestic euphemism for help. I went over with a bag full of uncertain solutions and found her sitting on a chair with a dish towel wrapped around her wrist and her mouth arranged at the angle that means she is behaving for my benefit. The skin was bruised but not broken, a small riot under good lighting. She told me, with the bored patience of a person who has had worse, about the neighbour who had started composting as if he were the inventor of the concept and how she had refrained from saying she had been composting since compost was called rubbish. We made tea in a way that made the kitchen remember why it had been built. I found an old elastic bandage in the cupboard where she keeps string and historical jam and we wrapped her wrist while she told me, without looking at me, that she had listened to the cassette again and this time she had laughed through the whole thing and then had to sit down. “He calls the robin ‘Robbin’ as if he’s heard something about someone else,” she said, and we both smiled the way you smile when you are letting something not hurt you on purpose. Before I left she insisted on going out to the shed to show me the way the light came through a crack at half past two and made a bright stripe across the bench exactly where my father had kept the small flat-headed screwdriver. We stood there while it did its afternoon miracle and I thought of the watchmaker telling me I was allowed to mean it when I turned something that had been asleep back on.

Eliot arrived the first week of March in a coat that had given up on keeping anyone warm and a bag of groceries he had bought because he had decided to perform normalcy and it had looked like this at the till. He put on my kettle like a man applying for a visa and unpacked fennel as if hoping to be forgiven before the smell arrived. We cooked in my kitchen with the awkward grace of two people offering each other an apology without agreeing on the terms. He cut onions with too much attention and cried with the concentration of a man who refused to make a metaphor out of it. We ate at the table, the watch ticking between us like a third companion who had agreed to refrain from comment. He told me he had started seeing a woman called Anu who asked him questions in a room with a rug, and I said, “Good,” as if he had remembered his keys. He told me he was learning to ask his sentences if they wanted to be cruel and to listen when they said no. I told him I was learning to forgive my worst drafts without congratulating myself for being magnanimous. We did not solve anything but we did not ruin anything, which, given our history, felt like a dare met.

At the next open mic, the penguin had acquired a badge that read, “I survived February,” which implies an administrative capability I endorse. Isaac read again and his father stood behind him like scaffolding. A woman from the college read a list about the things she puts in her pocket before going to work in the hospice and I stood outside after and let my chest hurt in the moral way. The men at Parc sent a new list for “The Cupboard” via the governor, who had decided that perhaps sometimes rooms do not need to be watched to behave. It included, “Count the crows and understand they have no duty to you,” and “Write the name of the person you loved most with your wrong hand and see if it teaches you anything you can use,” and “Learn one new knot, not just so you can tie things down, but so you can unfasten yourself with competence.”

On a Tuesday that pretended to be spring, the watchmaker in Topsham sent a text that consisted only of a photograph: my grandfather’s watch on her palm, the second hand making its dignified laps as if nothing had happened. When I went to collect it, she explained, in the tone of someone who trusts you with facts, that the balance had been out, that time is a negotiation between desire and constraint, that regulation is not a trick but a kindness. “You will still have to wind it,” she said, as if denying me a myth in which things fix themselves and stay fixed. “That will not change. Some work is meant to be daily. Otherwise you will think you have solved something that requires attention.” I paid her and tried to tip, and she refused in the old country way that taught me a great deal about the kind of person I want to be when the world lets me keep being a person. I walked back to the station with the watch in my pocket and my hand on it as if it were an egg I could keep from cracking by tenderness alone.

The large house sent a draft contract that had more capital letters than sentences and a clause involving a podcast that made me feel like a man being told he must learn to yodel to qualify for a library card. Clemency and I sat again at the table while the river blew itself out into a respectable wind and worked through it as if it were a stubborn knot. “This is nothing,” she said, brisk and warm. “This is a conversation we will have twice and then I will send an email that begins, ‘As discussed,’ which will frighten someone handsome.” We called the brooch editor and promised her a seat at the launch because there are ways to retain decency inside the machine and one of them is to tell the people who made you feel brave you are not leaving them for better canapés. In the evening I went to the allotment and put my fingers in the soil as if checking its pulse, and a robin—an actual robin, smug as heritage—sat on the fork handle and looked at me in that judgmental way birds do when they have decided to forgive you before you apologise. I misnamed it out loud, for form’s sake, and the air did not correct me.

At the winter fair’s late-arranged Spring Addendum, because this is a school and therefore any excuse for bunting will be found, I judged mini-eggs in nest cakes and discovered a new respect for the human capacity to arrange shredded wheat into the idea of safety. The headteacher introduced me to a boy who had written a poem with the line “I am the part that stays up when the river lies down,” and I resisted the urge to put him in my pocket for later. A woman I had once kissed badly in Year Eleven told me she had seen me on the television and that I looked taller and I forgave us both for everything.

One morning near the equinox I woke at five because an idea had come to sit on my chest like a caring cat. It was not a book; it was a list of ten letters to write to ten people, some of whom were alive and some of whom were not in a position to open the post. The titles wrote themselves on the page before the kettle had time to practice its opinions: To The Man Who Taught Me To Fold A Map, To My Teacher Who Let Me Pretend I Wasn’t Crying, To The Judge Who Said “Ordinary,” To The Boy Who Thought He Had Invented Shame, To The Woman Who Put A Toastie On A Plate And Made It Medicine. I wrote the first one with my fountain pen because sometimes the antiquity of an instrument will make your better self appear. When I was done, I read it aloud to the plant that has refused to die, and the plant behaved like an audience and held its breath; then it rustled, gently, and I took that as literary acclaim.

It rained and stopped raining the way March does when it cannot decide which story it wants to tell. The city found its daffodils. The gulls argued as if the subject were new for them. I met Eliot at the station and we walked the long way to the café so he could feed himself on the sort of buildings that had never learned to be ashamed of their age. He made a show of disliking the idea of scones and then ate two in a manner that would have made a vicar blush. We talked about the box again, and about the thing that happens when you let people watch you do something that is not a performance, and how it is not the watching that is the problem but the archive, the impulse to fix a moment so other people can admire themselves for catching it. “I want to be unrecorded,” he said, with a kind of defiance that felt like hope. “Just for a couple of weeks. I want to be bad at something and have it not matter.” I told him about the men at Parc and their lists, and he made the face they make in the city when a story arrives that cannot be improved by speed.

On the last day of the month there was a blackbird on the fence behind the allotment, and he sang like the city had made him responsible for something only he could deliver. I stood there with a trowel and a pocket full of seeds and let my face be what it was because there was nobody near enough to need saving from it. I could hear, distantly, the bells deciding to forgive us again, and closer by the sound of two boys practicing a dance badly and then better, and I thought, with the tidy satisfaction of a man who is learning how to count the right things, that I had written words this week that would not be ashamed to sit next to my grandfather’s watch on the desk. I wound it again, later, in the window, while the river remembered how to be gossip and the light remembered how to be kind, and on the cupboard shelf the good mugs stood with the sort of generosity that never thinks to advertise itself.

Chapter Ten

April arrived like someone had been dusting all night. The hedges along the towpath fattened with intent, and the river changed its mind twice before breakfast, doing that pale glitter it reserves for mornings when you are inclined to forgive it for yesterday. I found myself counting birds without asking to, not in the scientific way that puts a person in a hat, but in the way my father did, calling them by their wrong names until the right ones arrived like cousins late to a wedding. The watch came back from Topsham with an almost imperceptible swagger, the second hand doing laps as if the course had been altered to suit its dignity. I set it down on my desk and it ticked with a remorseless courtesy that made my laptop behave for a day, perhaps out of respect, perhaps out of fear of being shown up by a thing you had to wind to make it love you back.

The library said yes to our not-a-residency, and I loved it at once because the yes came wrapped in a risk assessment that included the words “benign proximity.” The head librarian, a woman who wore a cardigan like armour and whose smile had the exact wattage required to make teenagers return their books, led us to a corner between local history and music theory. We put two chairs there at an unshowy angle, so anyone determined to watch would have to tilt their head and discover the discomfort was their own invention. Eliot came down in a jumper that tried not to be expensive and a face that had resolved to be useful, and we sat for two hours not facing each other and wrote. People passed on their way to fines and forgiveness, some of them slowing to pretend they were interested in the shelf behind us, one or two going so far as to take down a book about canal engineering and carry it with the reverence of a prop that had found its way into their hands. A boy I did not know stood in the aisle for ten minutes and stared at his shoes until his mother arrived and sat down two tables away with the sort of patience that deserves a medal and is instead compensated with the soft satisfaction of watching her child pretend to be brave where bravery is cheap.

It is a curious relief to be seen in your ordinary position. I have become used to being asked to perform the domestic tricks of kindness at an angle that flatters the camera; sitting with my back neither straight nor slumped, arranging my mouth around a sentence that does not yet trust me was a defiance I did not know I needed. Eliot’s pen moved with the determined indecision I recognise in men who have taught themselves neatness as an apology, and every now and then he would stop and look up at a light fitting as if it were a line break he was hoping would blink first. An elderly man approached at one point with a plastic bag full of past and asked us, without asking us, to explain what on earth we thought we were doing making a living out of the nouns other people use for free. Eliot told him, very gently, that we were practising failure in public so it wouldn’t come as a shock later. The man nodded in a way that could have meant anything, took his books to the desk, and left a chocolate biscuit on the edge of my table like a tithe.

Clemency, who had been born between two meetings and will outlive several platforms, arrived halfway through and took a photograph so politely it almost didn’t happen. She perched on the radiator and whispered a running commentary to herself about jackets she had seen that day that had not deserved their buttons, and then handed me a printout of a schedule that looked like it had been designed to punish indecision. The large house had put together a list of cities and dates that made my knees behave like someone else’s, and the small press had countered with a list of rooms they could ask nicely and a bag of postcards that had been printed in a hurry and looked like it, which is how I prefer my future. We agreed, with the sort of speed only possible between people who already know the arguments, that we would call the book The Cupboard and arrange the essays like shelves, and that no chapter would be named after a virtue because the last thing either of us wanted was an index that sounded like a sermon.

I went back to Parc with a cardboard box full of the zine the brooch editor had coaxed into being from the men’s lists, and a head full of cautions about what it means to put a thing in print inside a place built to take away permanence. The officer with the wrist tattoo made a joke about autographing contraband and then checked my shoes for goodwill the way a parent checks a child for pockets full of frogs. The men came in with the energy of people who’ve been told there will be something new and are prepared to dislike it on principle, because principle is a shield that gets heavy but does its job. We wrote more for The Cupboard, this time a column called “What We Meant To Say,” and there were admissions about considerateness given too late and jokes not told because the room could not be trusted and the formulation of the sentence “I’m not angry, I’m disappointed” as wielded by a woman who deserved better. At the end we put the zine on the table and the men handled it like a small skittish animal, surprised by its weight, embarrassed by their own care. The man with the ridiculous ears put his copy under his jumper against his chest and declared he would read it with the respect he had never afforded a manual.

Isaac sent a poem to a competition and did not make the shortlist, and his email arrived with the politeness of a boy trying not to trouble a man he had only recently decided was safe. He wrote that he hoped he had not wasted anyone’s time and that perhaps his foxes were a bit ordinary, and then he apologised to me for saying ordinary like it was a slur. I wrote back longer than I meant to and told him that “not what you win” is not an alibi, it’s a technique, and that there is a thinness to certain kinds of recognition that you only detect when you hold them against the light of an actual afternoon. I told him to meet me by the war memorial with two poems and a packet of crisps and we read under a sky that had elected to be complicated. He had made something better in the gap between sending and not being chosen, and I told him a thing I wish someone had told me when I was seventeen and inventorying my heart: do not confuse quiet with failure; some work does its speaking after you’ve gone to make tea.

Imogen’s landlord’s idea about what the market could bear arrived on an official letterhead that looked like a man wearing cufflinks to a fight. She read it in the doorway with the dignity of a person who knows the difference between an overture and a threat, and then she called Ollie, who arrived with the relentless cheer of a person arming himself with posters. We convened an emergency of the sort that happens on pavements, where the wind has a vote and everyone’s practical jokes about capitalism turn, inconveniently, into practice. Out of this, overnight, grew a club we called “Custard First,” on the principle that some pleasures should be brought forward in case they are cancelled later by men who have never put jam in anything with love. The poster was a daffodil with fangs. People came in the way they come when they have been given a chance to demonstrate that they can carry part of the weight and would like to be permitted to. A woman brought a cake she had described as “unambitious” and which turned out to have ambitions large enough to require a licence. A man donated the takings from his dog grooming business for the afternoon because his clients’ poodles were experiencing a boom in self-esteem and he wanted to give back. We sold out of buns in an hour and I learned the precise dimensions of the human hand when it has decided to be a purse.

Eliot and I were briefly enemies again because of a paragraph neither of us wrote. A magazine decided that the narrative of rivalry wears well year-round and ran a feature on “Two Poets, One Country, Infinite Fuss,” in which photographs from four years ago were made to look like photographs from two months ago and sentences we had said in good faith were knotted so that they resembled wrists bound for entertainment. He sent me the link before I could find it, which is either cruelty or mercy depending on the temperature of your spleen, and typed, “I’m sorry they’ve made me into the person who says that about you.” I wrote back, “I’m sorry they’ve made you smaller than your worst day,” and then I put my phone on the table and went for a walk in the rain because some work requires weather to complete. Later, when we met for the two chairs not facing each other, we did the childish but effective thing of swapping a line each from what we were writing and promising to treat it with the kind of respect we had decided to ask the world for. He gave me a metaphor about hunger that wanted to be a train and I gave him a sentence about my mother’s hands that did not want to be pretty, and we both did slightly better work for the rest of the afternoon, which is an answer I will take.

The allotment woke with an offended cough, and I found weeds that had not existed in any previous cosmology making their intentions clear between the chitted potatoes. I staked peas with a desire that bordered on persuasion and accidentally planted runner beans in a formation that implied choreography. The man with the runner beans peered over the boundary wire like a neighbour in a children’s book and made a suggestion about windbreaks that contained three decades of knowledge and the precise number of knots required for a string to act like a promise. We drank tea from a flask like a prototype of companionship and he told me that tomatoes are personalities, not plants, and that my father had once sworn at a courgette for behaving like a metaphor, which I found so exactly right I had to sit down. The fork leaned where it always had, an upward insistence against a world that sometimes refused verticality, and I liked it so much I left it there on purpose.

My mother’s wrist healed with the furious speed of a woman determined not to be slowed for anyone else’s convenience. She developed a new contempt for step stools and a fresh respect for the floor, and began referring to her body parts in the third person as if they were colleagues she had to negotiate with. We established a new ritual that neither of us needed until then: Tuesdays were shopping and swearing, where we went to the big supermarket on the bypass and said rude things under our breath about the way they have started calling bread by its first name. She pushed the trolley with the authority of a woman who has lived too many lists and I followed like a man learning the choreography of responsibility. In the tea aisle she told me, unceremoniously, that she had been to the solicitor and had made a will and that I was to promise not to treat it like news when she died, which gave me an hour of bad temper I expended on the incompetence of an avocado. When we got home we ate cheese on toast that failed to be beautiful and succeeded in being food, and she told me Aunt Joy had thrown the fascinator a birthday party in the hope of exorcising it.

The book began to be a book. I arranged the pieces into shelves and Lerato, the editor at the large house whose emails were all verbs and mercy, wrote back with notes that made me feel both found and corrected. She suggested that the essay about the cupboard should arrive later, not because it was less important, but because she wanted it to feel like a room we’d been earning entry to, and I forgave her immediately because she had understood that a cupboard can be an ending. She asked if I had more about the men at Parc and I hesitated, because their lists are theirs and my job is not to colonise them, and together we found a way to talk about The Cupboard without pretending I had invented the idea that small tasks keep us alive. The title on the proof jacket looked like the name you give a ship that has no intention of sinking, and when the parcel arrived with two advance copies wrapped in paper that had decided to be modest, I opened one with the sort of care I normally reserve for birds that have hit a window and need to be reminded of the sky.

On a Sunday that smelled of wet dog and hope, the swifts arrived back in Exeter as if somebody had turned them on with their thumb. The air above Fore Street filled with their deranged sense of purpose and the city looked up with its mouth open, which is a look I recommend. It is impossible to be sincerely grumpy when the sky has decided to be a toy; even the cathedral, moody as a teenager before a school trip, offered sound that resembled enthusiasm. I wrote a short piece about them on the bench by the water, and it tried very hard to be a poem and refused, settling instead into the geography I have taught myself to trust, a list arranged in a way that allows a person to breathe. In it I wrote that swifts make a liar out of anybody who believes in neat returns, because they arrive as a mob and leave like a rumour, and that if we are understood by anyone with wings it is by accident and because we happened to be carrying a useful crumb. I read it at Power To The Buns and the penguin, who had survived a flood and a spring clean, glowered with the proprietorial expression of a bird that has never seen a sky and is fine with that.

Anu appeared in Exeter with the aura of someone who has stopped a man from performing himself into collapse for a living. She was wearing a green coat the precise shade of the river on a good day and had thoughts about bread that made me wonder if she had come from a country where bread is taken seriously and not in a museum. She watched Eliot and me read above the bicycle shop and did not applaud at the wrong moments, which is how I know she loved him in a way that might survive an argument about fennel. After, we drank beer that had opinions and she asked me questions that were not about my work and nodded in a way that suggested she was counting my adjectives and deciding whether to permit me to use them next time. I liked her with the sort of ease that usually embarrasses me, and when she left I realised something in the room had relaxed that had been ready for a fight without admitting it.

On the day the proof was signed off, I took the train to Dawlish with my mother and we sat on the sea wall holding paper cups that promised coffee and delivered optimism. The air did the thing it does when it decides to be brine first and weather second, and my mother told me about a boy she had taught who had written an essay about rivers and used the word “smug” correctly, and how she had nearly thrown him a parade for getting it right. I gave her the proof and she held it with the careful disrespect she reserves for objects that are not going to tell her how to live. She told me the dedication was all wrong and then said it was right enough and asked why the cover wasn’t blue, and I laughed like a man who had not spent three hours last week arguing about a title with the patience of a parson. On the way back she fell asleep the way only people who have earned it can, and I watched the red cliff faces perform their geology for men who take photographs of themselves in front of cliffs, and I decided that the next time the river sulked I would remind it that we are all behaving as best we can.

Linda’s cat learned a new way to look offended that involved an entire ear and the tilt of a head. She sent me a picture of him wearing, with the toleration of a saint, a ribbon that said “SUPPORT STAFF,” because she had been elected vice-chair of the parish fete committee by mistake and required moral muscle. Aunt Joy took up tap on a Wednesday morning class populated entirely by women who had learned that if you laugh first you get to control the joke, and sent us all a video of her feet functioning like punctuation under a sentence that had never previously known where to stop. Imogen raised her prices by ten pence and apologised in chalk for three days, and then allowed herself to be forgiven on the fourth and slept like a tree.

We did the first event for The Cupboard in Bristol in a shop that used to be a bakery and had not forgotten. People came wearing their best cardigans, some of them newly knitted into bravery, and brought their griefs in pockets and handbags like responsible citizens. I read the piece about the watch and the fork and the list of things you can do when the day is stubborn; Eliot stood at the back with Anu and made a face at a sentence I had not known I could write and mouthed “Yes,” which, from him, is like receiving a state honour that has learned humility. Afterwards a woman with a voice like early birds told me she had wound her husband’s pocket watch for the first time since he died and had expected a feeling like a poem and experienced instead a feeling like a shopping list, and we stood together in that and decided it was fair.

At the second event a man asked a weaponised question about whether kindness isn’t just a way of prettifying complicity and whether there were not better uses for our breath. I told him that kindness is a technique for not killing each other on the way to the argument we ought to have, and that I am in favour of ferocity but have found it makes a better tool when it sits in a drawer with string and tape and a pen that works. He harrumphed with academic zeal and bought two copies, one for a person he loved and one for a person he had not yet decided about, and when I signed them I wrote his name with too much care and hoped he noticed the insult I had refused to deliver and the respect I had delivered instead. On the train home I wrote a letter to the man who taught me to fold a map, which turned out to be my father disguised as a geography teacher I never had, and I cried in that rigid way men do when they suspect anyone might be watching, and nobody minded because there were swifts outside and a timetable to consider.

The watch ran down one night because I had not wound it, and the silence woke me at two with the delicacy of a burglar who is careful not to tread on toys. I lay there and listened to the not-tick and thought about daily work, about the lie of permanent fixes and the mercy of rituals you can go back to without apology. In the morning I wound it with intention and then wrote five hundred words before I looked at my phone, which is, in this economy, a revolution. When I did look, there was a message from Lerato with an attachment called “COVER_FINAL_FINAL” and a sentence about a blurb that had made her cry, and a text from the officer at Parc with a photograph of The Cupboard page on the education room wall with a fresh column added by one of the men called “If you can’t sleep,” which included, “rescue a memory from a thing and let it stay out all night,” and, “try to remember your mother’s handwriting without going to find it.”

May was ambitious and tried to be August for a week, which made Exeter behave like a Mediterranean city with a quiet sense of humour. Imogen put tables outside as if we were Paris and the penguin disapproved in a way that made passing dogs suspect him of leadership. Isaac finished his exams and read me a poem about fatigue that made a better case for rest than any doctor I have ever met, and his father shook my hand as if handing me the portion of pride he could not carry back to the car without spilling. Eliot and Anu came down for a weekend and slept in my spare room on a mattress that has ideas about people, and we went to Dawlish again because the trick with the trains never gets old if you’re honest with yourself. On the sea wall he admitted he had said yes to the magazine’s box and no one had died, and that he had spent his first two hours in it writing a shopping list in Latin because he had wanted to get the exhibitionism out of his system. Anu said she had made him a sandwich the shape of his better self and that he had eaten it without comment, which is the most flattering thing I have ever heard about a man in love.

On the last Friday of the month we did The Cupboard in a church hall with acoustic tiles and an unapologetic smell of boiled vegetables. The vicar was a woman with a laugh that had survived more light switches than I have ever flicked, and she told me that if I made one joke about God behaving like an absent landlord she would put money in the jar and call it theology. We made a long list together this time called “What to do when your mouth doesn’t know how to say it,” and it included, “teach your throat to behave with water,” and “borrow a sentence from a book and sit it in your mouth until it stops biting,” and “write ‘I cannot say this yet’ on a piece of paper and leave it where you will find it on a braver day.” At the end, the vicar bought six copies and the man who had asked about complicity apologised with the softest voice available to him, and the penguin, who had been watching from a folding chair, looked as though he would permit one hymn and no more.

June, while we were looking the other way, crept in and lifted the light to that late angle that makes even the tiredest of us consider staying up. The swifts wrote their arguments above the quay and the river decided to be a mirror even when it was not, and we sat in the library’s two chairs not facing each other and learned to let the room carry us. The book entered the world like any other domestic object that had been worked on and not ruined: it found its place and, occasionally, resisted being used for what it was meant for. People brought it back to me with fingerprints in the margins and accused me of getting away with short chapters, and teenagers sent me messages in which they thanked me for making lists look like a sufficient way to move through a day. I wrote to the man who had taught me to fold a map and to the teacher who had let me pretend I wasn’t crying and to the boy who thought he had invented shame, and somewhere between the letters and the lists and the watch’s quiet insistence, I forgot for a week to be on television and remembered entirely how to be in a room where someone has left a mug for you on the good shelf because they thought of you coming and decided to count that as joy.
